output: Thank you, Mr. President. I very much welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, that we get to the bottom of the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, whether we're talking about Ne Proffi, food labeling, or even in some parts of the White Paper, we fall back on a very one-sided approach.
we are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy
I believe that it is fundamentally the wrong approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Amendment proposals show that this does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or balanced and unbalanced, ways of eating.
should be our approach.
The causes of poor nutrition are multifaceted.
Trying to solve this by guiding consumers through product labeling, or even by imposing advertising bans or regulations, or by using different VAT rates, will not achieve our goal.

I believe that everything we are doing here is not meant to preempt the labeling regulation debate, but everything we are doing should fall under the heading: what can we do to motivate consumers to think about their eating habits?
In my opinion, a traffic light labeling that suggests to him that I am now facing a good or bad product is more an instrument of empowerment than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
that's why I'm hoping for a balanced approach here and the realization that the path through product policy alone won't get us anywhere. thank you very much, senior krammer, for the minute.
Mr President, Madam Vice-President, dear colleagues, budgetary control is not about new issues.
We are satisfied with the old ones and would also be satisfied with progress on the old topics.
At the top of our agenda is our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial control.
We don't want to be where we are today in two years. That's why this point is very, very important to us.
The second point is the declaration of reliability for the overall budget according to the tiered control procedure, including the national audit offices.
It would be great if we could make decisive progress in the last six months, during which the Commission will remain in office, or at least agree on a common path.
One becomes modest as a household controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We need to provide more help to the lower administrative levels of the Member States in implementing EU law.
It turns out that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law. This is also why the error rates are so high.
Fourth point: external aid. Here, I would like to address Kosovo in particular and the issue of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been to Kosovo, and I would like to announce now that Kosovo will play a certain role in the budget discharge.
I believe that we have fallen far short of the European Union's capabilities so far and that we urgently need to catch up in this area.
The fifth point would be to improve cooperation among member states in combating fraud.
We have homework here, primarily for the members of the Council.
The Parliament will vote on the legal basis for the anti-fraud regulation in November. Then we will have to think together about how to proceed if we want to achieve better results in this area.
has been, at least until now, our shared game of choice
Mr President, India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, especially at the level of so-called ordinary people.
business travelers, tourists, students, and so on. A brief note on this: it is also relevant to the Commission's legislative program that we discussed earlier.
In global air travel, we need good safety regulations, ones that are effective, not just mere alibi measures.
It would therefore be a sensible, truly necessary measure to finally abolish the nonsensical liquid regulations and come up with something better.
I voted in favour of the resolution because it is a clear call on the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, indeed fraudulent, parliamentary elections in September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.

At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between the peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens when entering the Schengen Area, thereby preventing increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
First, I would like to refute the notion, which I heard just a few minutes ago, that foreigners are flooding our job market.
Secondly, I would have liked a clearer, more unambiguous report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the social cohesion of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States and the European Court of Justice and not be satisfied with merely calling for a balance between fundamental rights and the freedoms of the internal market and free movement.
We will not change that. Fundamental social rights are, just like civil liberties, human rights that must not be restricted by the freedoms of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
It is time to amend the Posting of Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements cannot be limited to minimum requirements. Thank you.
Mr President, I would like to join in thanking the rapporteur Doris Ba, which has already been done quite rightly by many colleagues.
With her, we have someone who hopefully won't forget the passion, but invests a lot of passion in this room.
I am pleased with you and the colleagues who have also said that there have been some advances, including in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on the ground can also function in reasonable ways.

However, I still believe that we must repeatedly remind our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that a great deal still needs to be contributed by them, from their side, probably more than is currently being contributed in some areas.
The internal cooperation, the willingness to engage in this internal work within the ethnos is something we must constantly demand.
It's not a case of everyone trying to go their own way.
And also the integration into the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
Madam President, the distance between the European Union and its citizens must not become as great as it has become.
We need to make sure it is reduced in size.
In this context, the Ombudsman has an important task, especially when and where he does it well.
Above all, it is also about the fact that we must expect the Ombudsman to act with commitment and a sense of proportion.
The point is that we should not raise expectations that are too high for anyone to meet.

However, on the other hand, it is also about ensuring that wherever shortcomings have occurred in the administration of European institutions, these are addressed and, where possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can then reassure and satisfy the citizens.
Experience to date has shown that the Ombudsman takes this task seriously and does a good job of it.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case. And we thank you and the rapporteur for this report.
Colleagues, ten years after the realization of monetary union, Europe is in a severe crisis.
Banks are collapsing or are being supported with billions of dollars from the state budget. Sales are plummeting and millions of people are worried about their jobs and their future.
But not only has the market failed, the ruling politics also seem incapable of learning from their mistakes.
We believe that even with such interjections, you do not want to particularly distinguish yourself. We believe that serious mistakes were made in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
One such mistake is the structural separation of monetary and fiscal policy. You cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing tax and spending policies, at least in outline.
I think the economic imbalances in the Eurozone have become enormously worse.
What we need now is indeed better coordination of economic policies and, above all, tax policies.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, tax havens must be closed, and capital flows must finally be controlled again.
The second serious mistake is seen in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who considers household consolidation to be inevitable in times like these is obviously living in a different world. There would be nothing more disastrous than responding to this economic crisis with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our opinion, what is needed is an investment offensive to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of the socially disadvantaged in Europe.
We see a third mistake in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for democratic control of the European Central Bank and also demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, so that in the future, growth and employment must be promoted at least equally with price stability.
The current crisis also offers an opportunity for profound reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, honourable Members, the automotive industry is indeed in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
The financial crisis, in particular, has accelerated the crisis in this sector, and member states are currently working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And that is why we need European solutions for this key European industry in order to overcome the crisis.
Almost all car companies have European structures.

In order to make the necessary investments in environmental protection, which has been mentioned several times today, and to implement environmentally friendly and energy-efficient technologies, car manufacturers need public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supplier industry, which is very important, must not be forgotten in this context.
It is precisely in the supply industry, in small and medium-sized enterprises, where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the last plenary session, the Council President made a proposal to protect key industries.
a good proposal, in my opinion, because if you think this idea through to its logical conclusion, it amounts to a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
That would certainly be a good instrument.
But this protective instrument is currently being fought against by the European Commission.
My question to the Commission is: Will the European Commission persist with a lawsuit despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or will it change course in light of the crisis?
Dear Mr. President, Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors and Vice-President of the European Commission, dear colleagues! Indeed, it has become a tradition to note.
We must accept that, in the relationship between expenditure at European level and administration at national level, a declaration of assurance cannot be issued once again.

I can recall conversations with the former president of the Federal Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, given the structures, it is not at all possible to provide a reliability statement.
That is why we should start thinking about how this instrument can be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a declaration of assurance can be achieved when it is justified.
And of course we need to distinguish a few things from each other here.
Firstly, a budget that contains around 95% subsidies is much more prone to fraud than a national budget, or a regional or a municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states, has required much more independence from us in the new financial period, because the criticism in the last funding period was that too much was centrally controlled.
Of course, this also means that responsibility for the money must be taken on at regional and national levels.
I will only briefly address the third topic area.
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These are also things that are always thrown together.
I also get annoyed when EU funds are used to support things that are not absolutely necessary.
But that was not fraud, that was waste.

Therefore, those who are responsible for the projects, especially in the field of structural policy, the Member States, also have the responsibility to ensure that money is not wasted and that only projects which really generate added value for the region are promoted.
That is why we should consider converting parts of the structural policy into interest-free loans.
If you have to repay member states, then you only promote what you really need. Thank you very much.
I am not the only one who finds it difficult to agree with the self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to overcoming the financial market crisis.
This is why, if Europe, or the EU, were to be a functioning democracy, one would first have to ask the question of responsibility and how all of this could have happened.
It is simply not true that all the problems we face are a tsunami and something that is governed by natural law, but rather that they are man-made.
And with all the regulatory zeal that has characterized this Union, one wonders why action was not taken when banks began to cross national borders on a significant scale?
Why, despite appropriate warnings, did no action take place when derivatives crept in like this?
I remember well that Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz addressed all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That is where one must start, because recognizing one's own mistakes is the only key to finding solutions in the future.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner! My question is about what you think of Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a second currency.
Do you think that could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is: Do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the banks' equity capital?
My third question is: Do you not believe that a reduction in value added tax would accordingly support imports, especially from China and India?
would it not be more sensible to consider tax reductions for our businesses and for our workers, to pay investment premiums, and to adjust the progressive depreciation accordingly?

The focal point is that, above all, the value of low-value economic goods is increased by a factor of 10, so that apparent profits are not taxed, the money remains in the enterprises, and thus wages can also be paid better.
Madam President, the comprehensive report highlights the numerous human rights violations that occur daily around the world.
This is particularly alarming 60 years after the declaration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and calls on us to intensify our efforts.
This is also why I would like to advocate for the current Subcommittee on Human Rights to be established as a main committee.
Today we awarded the Sacharov Prize to Hojia, who is committed to human rights and the environment in China.
However, because he is incarcerated, he was unable to take possession of it in person.
Shame on China! and tomorrow there will be a debate here on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, not only economic interests, but above all human rights, must be given a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hodjia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, dear colleagues! As rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one gains interesting experiences, such as the fact that everyone talks about combating fraud and then no one does anything.
Or the experience that the member states calculate their payments to the European Union with a fine-tipped pen, but when it comes to spending this money, they put on their spending pants.
and even make it easy for fraudsters, for example, by the fact that it still takes an average of 36 months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament disagrees with this.
We want efficient fraud prevention that also includes prevention.
We want the member states to make the fight against fraud a priority and for us to discuss the necessities and challenges together.
We want to see greater interest from national judicial authorities in following up on OLA mediation results.
In the case of prosthetics, there can no longer be areas free of rights as there have been in the past.
We need to equate European money with national money.
We want an independent agency that has the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
We want an office that can work seamlessly and efficiently with the member states.
Our opinion on legal basis 17399 covers all these points.
We advocate for further developing this regulation as the core of the anti-fraud office, in collaboration with the Council.
We urge the Council to incorporate our opinion. We urge the Council to begin discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We want to bring OLAF's problems to a solution.
I thank all the factions of the High House for supporting this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up Parliament's ball and pass it back.
In our proposals, we have also incorporated solutions developed and submitted by the Council working group.
On our part, I can tell you that we are interested in a swift conclusion of this regulation and assure you of our constructive willingness to engage in discussions based on our proposals.
Consolidation of all OLAF legal bases, as envisaged by the Council, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Ola will soon be celebrating his tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We take fraud prevention too seriously for that.
We want that because we can do it now, in cooperation with the Council.
thank you very much
Mr President, I would like to take up a point that my Austrian colleague Paul RÃ¼big raised earlier.
We spend less than 1 percent of European gross domestic product on Europe, and at the same time we demand that the European Union should handle more and more tasks for more and more member states.

This accounting method cannot be sustained. It is therefore truly unbelievable that we have been pursuing an austerity course for many years, but this austerity course is not only limited to being frugal.
It is not about using our funds effectively, but rather about allowing finance ministers to collect money at the end of the year and incorporate it into their domestic budgets.
We would have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not really adequately budgeted for in years.
I believe that the European Union's information funding needs to be significantly increased if we really want to connect European citizens to Europe.
There are many tasks in the area of student and apprentice exchange that Europe could deploy here.
This is also advancing in the justice sector, a traditionally state-reserved area.
This corresponds to the changed living conditions of people in our Union.
But - and this point has already been made several times - integration must not interfere too much with traditional, well-established structures, especially those that are already functioning well.
Not everything can be swept under the rug.
Public records and public notaries are structured quite differently in many member states.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notary profession as a public authority for authentic documents has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This should not be jeopardized unnecessarily, just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual openness are a good thing, but in moderation.
Thank you, Madam President, esteemed colleagues! Plant protection products have been and remain essential inputs for agriculture.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products because it is about protecting the native cultural landscape, providing high-quality nutrition, and conserving resources.
We discuss chemicals all too often on a very irrational level.
But in order to get sensible results, we must think and act rationally.

The consequences of the original parliamentary position would have been fatal: a broad ban on plant protection products would have led to lower agricultural yields and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am glad that a barely acceptable compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is commendable that we have maintained the three-zone regulations, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different. In addition to acceptable compromises, we should not pre-empt a final definition of endocrine-active substances, but actually give the EU Commission the four years of time to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be stretching the precautionary principle at this point.
and finally, I find it regrettable that we did not take the initiative to initiate a follow-up assessment of the agreement that has now been reached. Thank you.
The last time there were similar statements during a visit by a head of government or state, the President of this House intervened most decisively.
At that time, it was about an issue that was important to him personally, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When the president, the sovereignly elected president of a country, speaks today and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the president does not intervene.
Do you know what that is?
This is not democracy, this is arbitrary rule, and I demand that appropriate measures be taken.
Minutes Children and politics: Rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so widely.
The issue of children is at the top of the agenda for citizens across Europe.
For politicians, children's interests are a distant concern, as we can see once again here.
I know of no country that has its own Ministry for Children. Nor does the Commission have its own representative for the interests of our youngest citizens.
The issue of children is spread across all parliamentary committees.
That is why I would like to particularly emphasize to the Commission at this point that it is dealing with childcare facilities and Barcelona targets today.
! In our parliamentary working group on Quality of Childhood, we have found that our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here and now is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb all the way to the top of the social ladder or fall all the way to the bottom.
It can remain in its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
They may follow a similar life path to their parents or do exactly the opposite.
One can marry someone of the opposite or the same gender.
All of this was completely different more than 50 years ago, when we founded the Association of Europeans.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans has become a determining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore be incorporated into the pedagogy of child educators and teachers.
This is still far too little taken into account at present.
Europe's childcare facilities and schools are indeed struggling with the challenge of integration.
In matters of integration, we need to press the reset button and go back to the beginning.
Let's approach this topic once again completely free of prejudice, in accordance with the motto "Unity through Diversity."

Furthermore, I ask all the Members of the European Parliament who follow me not to advocate only for gender mainstreaming. Please also advocate for children's mainstreaming, especially now during the global financial crisis, because otherwise we will be imposing immeasurable debts on our children. Thank you very much!
Mr President, I want to keep this very brief.
I am very grateful for the constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.
I would just like to send out two final messages. Firstly, I would like to expressly thank the Commissioner for not fundamentally opposing the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net.
This proposal is neither the work of the devil nor a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving tool that we should give a chance.
that's why I would like to advocate for it again at this point.
and the second thing I want to say, and this is now directed at my British friends, is: cross all the parties
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline, I do understand your problem.
I can well understand that a country might prioritize energy security over compliance with an air pollutant limit value for a certain period.
I have great understanding for that.
I am also the last person who would not give Her Majesty additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is, we haven't done exactly that.
This conversation has never taken place over the last four months.
I would like to ask you to remain open-minded about this at this point in the second reading and to say let's discuss a compromise on this point and
to give up the fundamental opposition to the minimum standards, which in my view is completely irrational and not justified from a competition policy or environmental policy perspective.
I believe that this is the point where a compromise can be reached, which I hope will also be achieved in the second reading.
Incidentally, I do not believe that we should not seek a compromise in the first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.

I do not want to end this legislative term as rapporteur and leave the next Parliament with legislation in which a legislative text is being discussed that is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
That is why I ask for your support for the compromises when we vote here in an hour. Thank you very much.
Ladies and gentlemen, I believe the crucial question regarding all the economic stimulus programs currently being developed across Europe is, of course, who ultimately receives the money?
We will continue to issue blank checks to the banks, even though rapid nationalization would ultimately be significantly cheaper for the taxpayer.
And are the corporations and high-income earners to be further relieved, even though they have been fattened up for years throughout Europe with tax gifts?

The more money is squandered on such purposes, the more foreseeable it becomes that such programs will fail, and the more likely it is that the European economy will continue to sink into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, liberalization - this very policy has increasingly concentrated income among the top 10,000, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
Who believes that he can overcome this crisis by continuing to pursue exactly this policy with minor modifications? I think that person simply hasn't understood anything at all.
The exact opposite of this is needed.
Instead of buying up bad debts from banks, tax money should be used to renovate schools, hospitals, and to restructure the European economy in an environmentally friendly way.

If private companies receive public funds, it must be clear that no tax money is given without employment guarantees and, above all, no tax money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can also share in the future profits.
The best economic stimulus program currently available would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from top to bottom.
The gig economy sector in Europe must be pushed back, instead of being promoted further and further.
We need higher minimum wages and we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and the beneficiaries of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have been incurred, and not the vast majority of citizens who never benefited from the financial boom in the first place.
I believe that the socially just is currently also the only economically sensible approach.
It is the only way to address the devastating crisis dynamics.
Mr President, in early March, political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be charged again on the basis of untenable accusations.
The first public hearing day was scheduled for March 31.
On the same day, the EU-Russia human rights consultations were supposed to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed by the Russian side indefinitely.
Russia is thus demonstrating very clearly the low priority it places on human rights.
The judiciary continues to be used not only to dispense justice, but also to silence regime opponents, and the EU is being doped as a result.
Mr. Commissioner, Thank you, dear colleagues! I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again addressing the issue of the ban on animal testing.

has pointed out, because it reminds me that this is now the third amendment to the cosmetics legislation that I have been able to follow through: the sixth amendment, the seventh amendment, and now the amendment to a regulation.
And we have indeed managed to ban animal testing.
We have managed to ensure that consumers, for example, know how long a product will last by seeing a small can with a number that indicates how long it is still valid.

I also say this to some of my colleagues, especially to my colleague Reuteko Reutova, who unfortunately could not be here at the beginning. Labels are never warnings at any time. If a product is not safe, it should not be on the market, it should not be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and harmless.
But the labeling gives consumers the opportunity to choose.
That is democracy, and that is your freedom of choice.
I believe it would be very good legislation.
I have tried to make the process very transparent.
I have tried, as Mrs. Crostet also said, to bring together different opinions.

Because I am concerned that we create legislation that is good for everyone: for the consumers of the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.
Mr. Colleague Stellhard, I say once again, yes, the DO works differently for everyone, but we made the statement that it keeps them sweat-free anyway.
That is why it is important that the statements regarding my wrinkle depth around the eyes after a week in Strasbourg are reasonably realistic and reliable.
I would like to express my thanks once again to the Commissioner, also for the explanations he has given to my fellow Members and to my staff, who have done most of the work.
thank you very much

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, the report by our colleague Vanisterol on the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most significant reports of the Committee of the Regions in recent years.
We agree with the basic concept of the Green Paper, which states that territorial cohesion is about addressing the polycentric development of the
to ensure overall sustainable development of the territories with different characteristics and features, while preserving their diversity.
It is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of phased assistance will be introduced for transition regions that cross the 75% threshold.
a clear status must be created for these regions so that they can exceed the level of the mainland product and thus have more security in their development.
In Ms. Krehe's report on obstacles to the absorption of Structural Funds, the most significant shortcomings faced by applicants are rightly listed.
The Structural Funds are subject to various obstacles, such as excessive administrative burdens, too many complex regulations, and slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the Member States.
Numerous recommendations are made to the Commission regarding effective measures to be taken to overcome these obstacles.
I would like to single out and emphasize two such measures.
Firstly, project managers must keep their project documents for a period of ten years, in order to have them available for inspections, which are also carried out by the Commission.
This is particularly an excessive bureaucratic effort for smaller projects.
It is true that this is now to be reduced to a period of three years. Secondly, the EU Commission's evaluation criteria for innovative projects are causing significant problems.
Innovative projects cannot be evaluated using the same criteria as other projects.
It is simply necessary for something different to happen here.

Madam President, when Europe takes money into its hands and when, above all, the Member States take a lot of money into their hands to help the automotive industries in their crisis situation, then it cannot only be about securing the status quo and preventing stagnation, but it is about a number of other concerns.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about providing people with employment opportunities, but they also need to secure these jobs in the long term.
To achieve this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all sustainability in the transportation system more strongly than we have done so far.

We should therefore link all our measures to these objectives so that we do not have to face criticism in a few years' time. We should have thought about all this many years ago, and then we would not be in the next and new crisis.
Thank you very much, Madam President! It would be nice if you could also grant me the extra half a minute that my Green colleague, Mrs Breyer, has just received.
The Commission has put forward a good proposal to update the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some proposed amendments attempt to supplement this proposal with provisions that are not compatible with the objectives of the regulation or even seek to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with a view to animal health and welfare would simply overwhelm traders.
And once again, there is an attempt to undermine the existing GMO laws, namely the demand for special labeling of such novel foods derived from animals that are fed genetically modified feed.
We just heard it. I think
In principle, anything that affects the GMO legislation should not be included in the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this even though I myself, for example, submitted a proposal to specifically exclude new plant-based products from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be that interested parties in this house misuse the Nobel Food regulation for electioneering purposes.
This appears to be the case with proposed amendments 62 and 90, for which the Greens have requested a recorded vote.
Which esteemed colleagues do you want to expose in this way?
My group has always been in favor of the consumer's right to know what is in their food.
Why, then, should one not indicate a nano origin in the declaration of ingredients?
And although Amendment 62 somewhat clumsily attempts to anticipate my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling from Noble Food to be quite compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend that my group approve the aforementioned motions and will include references to the section of the Novel Food Regulation dealing with labeling in my report on the Food Labeling Regulation.
This is possible because we postponed the first reading on foot labeling to the next legislative term, against the wishes of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement was.
Briefly, cloning is animal cruelty.
We are against it.
Nevertheless, food products must be included in this regulation accordingly, because otherwise they would be subject to a different legal framework.
Madam President, it's quite simple.
If anyone does not want this man to chair the solemn opening session of the European Parliament, they should support my motion to amend the Rules of Procedure.

Madam President, Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues, I want to make one thing clear: In the upcoming vote on our colleague Tschickerski's report, the issue of donating food to those in need, especially in these economically difficult times, is not up for debate.
That is why I would like to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common line within our group.
I therefore respect the personal decision of each group colleague to deviate from this and not to agree with the rejection of the report that we have planned.
Why can I not agree with the outcome of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this, which have nothing whatsoever to do with helping those in need in the European Union during these economically difficult times.

On the contrary, the amendments submitted by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ArtEFction, which were unfortunately not found to be admissible, were intended to place the existing system on a sustainable footing.
Because the current system is an anachronism from the days of agricultural overproduction, which fortunately belong to the past.

However, I also want to make two things very clear, which in my opinion should be understood as critical remarks.
In a few minutes, at 12 o'clock, this Parliament will vote on my report on the Director-General's White Paper on competition.
We will demand from the European Commission, with an overwhelming majority in this House, that a horizontal approach be adopted in dealing with this issue.
It cannot be that we end up with sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, another for antitrust law, another for the capital market, and perhaps another for the environment.

Perhaps one more for social affairs, and they all contradict each other. They all interfere with the legal systems of the member states and ultimately lead to a legal and political mess that no practitioner can handle anymore.
We have had such examples many times in the past.
I am only thinking of the debate on the Professional Qualifications Directive, which we later also summarized in one instrument because this fragmentation was no longer tenable.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here.
It should promote the horizontal approach sequence from the outset.
This is the clear stance of the Parliament. This will become evident in a few months, in a few minutes, right here.

Last but not least, I am also very pleased that we have reached a consensus that we do not want a lawsuit industry along American lines, with US sales of 240 billion dollars per year, where ultimately only lawyers profit and consumers gain nothing from it.
We want genuine rule of law in Europe and to remain true to our traditional systems and our understanding of law.

Mr President, I share the rapporteur, Jules Savary's, regret that the Commission has not pursued its original plan for an integrated action plan.
There are many good reasons why all parties involved, from local communities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that the current traffic conditions are far from optimal.
Therefore, in principle, I agree with the plan and the report by my colleague Mr Savary, here from the Parliament's initiative to develop corresponding integrated proposals.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the concrete suggestions.
At the same time, however, I would like to make it very clear that what many fear or believe they must fear will not happen.
No one wants to take away the right of municipalities, local and regional authorities, to shape their own traffic conditions.
From the European side, we merely want to contribute to ensuring that reasonable, common rules are followed here, if a municipality, if a city, if a regional entity deems it reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not compromised.
What we want to do here is to protect this principle.
It therefore remains that we strive, in the interest of citizens, to ensure that it is not when a citizen travels 10, 20 kilometers
Europe continues to drive, he comes across a traffic-calmed zone that he believes he knows from his home town, but finds completely different rules there.

No one wants to impose any city ordinances or other regulations on any communities, but if they are actually implemented here, then they should also be put into a recognizable framework for the citizens.
For more than 100 years, we have agreed on the usefulness of common approaches when it comes to traffic signs.
This should also be the case in the future with this topic.
Mr President, we have been dealing with urban transport in the EU for a long time now.

Supporting measures, that is our task.

Our cities need tailor-made solutions, but these can only be developed by the local actors, because they are the ones who know what is necessary.

This is important for a city's attractiveness.

Our society is becoming older after all.

We need a supply of everyday goods close to where people live if we want to reduce traffic, and this is also a challenge for the retail sector.
Anything else would only require a green field.

I fully support the Commission's goal of establishing a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle for the standard introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, makes the urgency clear to me almost daily. But intelligent traffic systems can do much more.
They serve environmental compatibility, efficiency improvement, safety enhancement, non-discriminatory competitiveness, and road freight and passenger transport.

Furthermore, they support comodality, among other things, by developing interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways, and air transport, where the integration of intelligent transport systems has already begun.
All of this cannot be achieved by the Member States alone, but only as a Community task.

Intelligent transport systems based on EU-wide binding, fundamental standards and regulations for minimum quality improve the environment for innovation and create planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent traffic system services.

The action plan finally includes a schedule for the introduction of individual systems: A for road safety, such as ESP and eCall, B for continuity in traffic management, for example, information will be
Avoid toll fees or parking lot management search traffic. C The use of real-time road, traffic, and travel data will enrich not only professional drivers, but all road users.
The directive aims to establish detailed requirements for the EU-wide, uniformly binding, and coordinated introduction of intelligent transport systems and their application in the member states.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.
But beware: The introduction of intelligent traffic systems incurs high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We still know too little about the willingness and ability of potential users to pay.

My reasons are primarily concerned with the way the European Commission has handled and managed the accessions of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high level of corruption, with a lot of money, with a lot of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only began to freeze these funds in 2008.
We lost a lot of money in 2007 and now we have to deal with barely any control systems or with control systems that only function intermittently.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high rate of corruption and problems with the judiciary.
All of this is to be attributed to the accession process.

I want to set an example, also to tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently for future accessions and also to tell it that, if it has already been observed in other countries, it could certainly be more successful if it wanted to be.
I would like to call on the Commission to help the two countries build financial control systems that deserve the name and to help eliminate the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we will have a permanent problem and a permanent cause for concern for all of Europe. Thank you.

The fundamental flaw is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is intended to be granted to EU citizens, but not to other people living in Europe.
The same citizens and human rights are not to be granted to them.
On the one hand, the EU wants to join the Charter of Human Rights, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are sorted out according to the principle of legal or illegal.
This is how Frontex is being equipped to massively combat so-called illegal migration, and I tell you that this completely distorts the view of an unbiased immigration policy.

Mr President, regional structural funding is an essential instrument in European integration, and Objective 2 funding in particular has been perceived by people in the past as a driving force for local structural and economic development in many regions.
It is an important element for coping with structural change in the regions and also in the municipalities.
Here, Europe is truly tangible for the citizens, because it has a real impact on their daily lives.
However, we need simpler, clearer, and more transparent structures for the cohesion funds and better controls to ensure that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the convergence in social and economic development, is a key objective in the EU, and therefore we must not weaken these instruments in the future, but rather strengthen them.
Cohesion policy in Europe needs more clarity, more transparency, efficiency, and also the self-responsibility of the individual member states.
That is why it is important to stick to the system of additive support.
However, we do not want a renationalisation of structural funding.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to ensure that the funding criteria from 2013 meet these requirements.

It seems to me to be a bit symptomatic for us, and for the EU in general, but also for this Parliament in particular, that we reflexively engage in discussions about situations in countries whose situation is not new.
Unfortunately, it is often the case that subsequent events lead to us suddenly expressing ourselves in a wave-like manner in political forums, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe it does not behoove us to use a failed airliner attack alone to spark a general debate about Yemen.
I believe that we should be clear about the fact that it suits us well to consider a strategy for how we deal with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a thorough analysis, namely that it is a failed state in which a government operates that no longer has control over large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks this poses for Europe.
The risks seem to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is obviously taking place.
that's why I think it's important for us, and perhaps also for Mrs. Ashton, to consider what we can do against these risks
In my view, the answer is primarily: How can we support the government in Yemen in regaining control over the country and mitigating these risks?

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country must of course also be held. But I do not believe it is really sensible, and that we will be taken seriously, if we now present a list of demands across all political issues, from freedom of the media to women's rights here in Parliament.
I believe that will not achieve the goal in Yemen, but we should focus on what kind of help we can provide in the current situation to solve an acute problem. Thank you very much.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the massacre on 23 November last year in the Maguindanao province in the Philippines was a black day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
57 dead raped women, the wounded speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, I am particularly struck by the fact that among the dead were thirty journalists.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, no other documented case has ever seen more journalists murdered in a single instance.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, as the EPP, we are calling for the present text to be mitigated in three places through separate voting, because we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence and therefore refrain from making accusatory remarks towards the government.
Therefore, on behalf of the EPP, I request a separate vote on operative paragraph F, which accuses the Philippines of displaying all the signs of a non-functioning legal system.
In point two, we would like to remove the assumption of so-called initial delays in the investigation.
Finally, point six claims that there are missing persons who are being held in Philippine prisons.
This, too, is currently an unsubstantiated allegation and should, in our opinion, be deleted. Thank you.

Policy coherence for development means that we do not take away with one hand what we give with the other.

For example, it makes little sense to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries if we are simultaneously destroying local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
No matter how much we advocate for better healthcare, we cannot achieve it if we hinder the use of generics or drive up drug prices to unaffordable levels through patent extensions.

And while agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU to some extent, they lead to deforestation and land conversion in developing countries, resulting in more climate change, which is exactly what we wanted to avoid, not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and reduced arable land for food production.
At the moment, we - that is, the EU as such - are not particularly coherent.
The EU has long recognized in theory that policy measures should not contradict each other.
The Lisbon Treaty enshrines policy coherence in the interest of development.
Article 208 states: When implementing policies that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take into account the objective of development cooperation.
We must measure ourselves against this demand.
This year we will review the progress made towards achieving the Millennium Goals.
It is clear that without policy coherence, we will not be able to fulfill our promises.

We must be aware of this responsibility, like all of us who make and implement laws. Before we decide on a measure, there must be an impact assessment so that we can even recognize what European legislation could have negative effects on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, Commission and Parliament that can identify inconsistencies.
The Commission's work programme on policy coherence is a good step in this direction.
And now it depends on how this plan is implemented.
Policy coherence for development means that we must take greater account of the interests of local people in fisheries reform and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing companies.
It means that we must dry up the tax havens into which funds from developing countries flow.
This means that we cannot agree to ACTA if there remains a suspicion that this agreement could hinder access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the Commission has not been able to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that, in the creation of the diplomatic service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the powers of the development commissioner must be expanded, not restricted.
And it also means that we enable fair trade in the allocation of contracts in the municipalities, as my colleague Heide RÃ¼le has proposed.
In many cases, we need to keep a close eye on the Commissioners and the Council to ensure they develop coherent policies.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us Members of Parliament to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to network better between committees, and we need a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Development Committee has unanimously adopted, makes many good suggestions and takes us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can be adopted by the plenary tomorrow as well.

Madam President, dear colleagues, we have been discussing the issue of driving times and working hours in road transport for months.
I wonder what arguments will now be put forward to prove that what we have been discussing for months is all nonsense.
The latest argument is that something urgently needs to be changed here so that nothing changes.
Don't you see, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argument has become, how riddled it is with lies and half-truths.
This debate is about nothing other than an extension of working hours for self-employed individuals.
For the past 150 years, labor law has essentially been about protecting people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both self-employed individuals and employees.
It doesn't matter whether you're a self-employed person who's overworked or an employer who's overworked an employee driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessively long working hours, partly also from employers and clients.
Secondly, in terms of road safety, it is claimed here that nothing can happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not at a DIY store, and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws based on the principle of "let's see what comes out of it."
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours are designed to be accident-prone, especially in road traffic with major consequences.
Third point: Who is going to enforce the deradicalization scheme you envision on our streets in the future?
Today, a state labor judge cannot verify whether someone appears to be self-employed or is self-employed without extensive review of the case files.
let's stop this nonsense, it's about fair competition
It is not a matter of setting a precedent this morning for the future dispute over the extension of working hours.
Don't play games like that with this house. Thank you!

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, just a few days ago, we were shocked to see extensive areas of Poland and other Central European countries flooded by water on our television screens.
People have perished in the floods, and our deepest sympathy goes out to their families. Entire towns, agricultural land, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images. However, the enormous damage still needs to be laboriously cleared up.
In dealing with damage of this scale, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
After the 1997 flood disaster, Poland and this time also other Central European countries have once again been affected by a flood disaster.
We cannot yet regulate the weather, and flooding is a characteristic feature of rivers at certain times.
But the questions we need to ask are whether, in the awareness that these natural events can always occur, the right measures for prevention are in place.
were affected by such natural disasters and whether, for example, landscape planning adequately addressed issues of sustainable disaster protection.
When aid is provided, it should first and foremost benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster in order to secure their livelihood.

However, in international cooperation, efforts to prevent damage caused by natural disasters should no longer be limited by national borders. Instead, they should be coordinated at the European level by the member states.
The flood protection along the Oder River, which has so far been jointly developed by Polish and German authorities, demonstrates that joint company-level preventive measures can provide protection.
But we have not yet reached the end.
We don't need a European disaster protection agency.
Protecting its country from disasters should be the primary task of a country's government, which should also include the development of disaster plans.

But coordination of aid in the event of damage or incidents should also be subject to efficient European coordination, and those organizations that provide rapid and non-bureaucratic assistance on a voluntary basis should not be left to bear the costs.
Therefore, I support Commissioner Georgieva's plans to do this quickly.

A Europe without dividing borders is not feasible without a functioning transport system, and the European economy would not be successful, not even conceivable, without a powerful transport system, without powerful, future-proof transport systems on land, water, and in the air.

Why?

To unilaterally burden the Cohesion Fund and to relieve the Member States, which are particularly challenged, of the responsibility for ensuring a sustainable future for transport.

Ladies and gentlemen Commissioners, dear colleagues, one sometimes wonders what we have actually been doing for the past year with all these discussions and debates, and all those meetings in the trialogue, where I could have imagined myself doing something more enjoyable than spending time there.

At this point, more than a year after the European elections, when we were still proclaiming in the streets and squares how we intended to tame the financial markets, we are actually facing a very meager to non-existent result.

We are dealing with markets that operate globally today.
The member states still believe that they are able to enforce rules in this area with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely because that didn't work, he also contributed not to the financial crisis itself, but to its spread to Europe.

That's why I wonder when this realization, which is often expressed in Sunday sermons, will be translated into political action, where it suddenly becomes a matter of protecting stock market places, protecting banking structures, and no longer protecting citizens.

We in the European Parliament have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also dedicate themselves to it, because they share the responsibility for implementing proper supervisory rules that ensure that individuals' savings remain secure in the long term.
Of course, I hope, gentlemen Commissioners, that everything is now being done on the part of the Commission to achieve a good result as quickly as possible, in the interests of the people of Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen, we in the European Parliament have a responsibility to ensure strong regulation of the financial markets.
All that we had proposed was greatly watered down in the trilogues.
Council and government do not want strong intervention rights.
Giegold is right to call what is happening at the moment "tower-building thinking".
The intention does not seem to be to create poor regulation, but rather to design the system to be a little more fail-safe.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will not be able to exercise real control over the financial markets.
Inadequate conclusions are being drawn from this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, and in doing so, the next crisis is already being prepared.
Many national economies, including in Europe, will not survive the next blows, with all the social and economic consequences for the people in Europe.
They expect that this predatory financial market capitalism will be reined in and that the primacy of politics will be restored.
When the CEO of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, states over the weekend, "We need a strong and unified European financial supervisory authority and a common set of rules for..."
If member states are advocating for stricter capital rules, then this is an appeal to this Parliament to actually establish these rules.
It is up to this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to urgently implement effective regulation. This would only be the first step towards a status quo.
Finally, let the big promises be followed by actions. My faction stands for strong European regulation.
Anything else but regulation would be a danger to the euro, to a united EU, and to democracy. Thank you.

Madam President, esteemed High Representative, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues! The recent events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people,
The burning of houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who left their homes and tried to flee the violence - all of this has shaken me and evoked compassion for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan also shed light on the situation in Central Asia, which must not leave us in the European Parliament untouched.
On the contrary, we should devote our full attention to the countries in this region.

In this context, we should focus not only on the countries that are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but rather consider all countries on an equal footing within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
That is, I, our commitment.
The Central Asian states, which freed themselves from the once Tsarist and later Soviet rule less than 20 years ago, carry a heavy legacy.
Arbitrarily drawn borders by Stalin, without regard for the home region of the peoples living there, apparently complicate coexistence within and beyond the borders of these states.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions such as those in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan - hundreds of thousands
Forced labor migration and, as now admitted in Kyrgyzstan, the use of violence to resolve conflicts, leave the future path of these states uncertain.
Here, the European Union cannot simply stand by and watch.

If we do not want to lead these countries down a path towards fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to hand their people over to dictatorial regimes for the long term, we need to make a full commitment.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we need contact with these states and active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbaeva a chance to pacify Kyrgyzstan and lead it towards stable political conditions. Let us allow her the opportunity to debate this here and vote on it tomorrow.

We are determined to follow up on our words with actions, so that the people in Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states can feel that we will not leave them alone on their path to the future or abandon them to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high. We should not disappoint them.

Mr President, Commissioner, I am very much in favour of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else entirely.

Cloning is animal cruelty. And many colleagues have already said that here.
I also raised this point before the summer break in the discussion we had. Only a fraction of animal clones are actually viable.
and those who survive, of whom many, many die very early and in a very painful manner.
suffer from malformations of extremities of organs
They have weakened immune systems, they are susceptible to illness.
This means pain and suffering and this agonizing death.
Can we really be responsible for that?
We are committed to animal welfare, and then we want to support such a technique.
No, we do not want that, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want any cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is only consistent.

Yes, we know that the products from the cloned animals or their descendants are probably not harmful to health, and I personally assume that they would actually be suitable for human consumption. But there is actually no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we engage in this cloning?
It is completely unnecessary to engage in this cruelty to animals. The population simply does not want it.
The public does not want these products, and we do not need them either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
That is why we want a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and also for their offspring.
I want a ban on cloning and cloned products in the European Union, and I also believe that we can enforce this.
Of course I must also relate this to imports.
I want to be sure that I am not being secretly served cloned meat because it is not labeled, as has already happened here.
"But I don't think you can trace all meat back to its source."
The beef market may be possible.
But with pork, due to the volume produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether there was ever a clone in the lineage.
Basically, I think yes, it is a matter of principle, it is an ethical question.
And colleagues have said it: We must also deal with ethical issues, and we are also responsible for ethical issues.
There is, of course, the issue of animal welfare, but there is also another issue.
Experience shows that all reproductive techniques, once they really worked in animal production, were ultimately also applied to humans.
So today we must ask ourselves: Do we want and can we use cloning technology in the not too distant future? Can and do we also want to accept it in humans?
Well, I don't want that, and I can't do that either.
And even if we could clone a spare part, a clone of myself, that could donate a vital organ in the future, I wouldn't want that.
I don't think that's an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that this would be possible in the not too distant future if we were to allow cloning.
That is why we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on clones and their offspring throughout the EU.
I am not afraid of the WTO.
We can enforce this.
We don't have to copy everything the USA does, despite all the transatlantic friendship.

Dear Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we talk about mountain regions and sparsely populated areas, I get the impression from individual contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.

Each of these territories belongs to a Member State, which is sovereign.
The implementation of European decisions and objectives is still the responsibility of the Member States, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.
When I look at the European level, we have always paid special attention to these areas - mountain regions, sparsely populated areas, islands - in Commission communications up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here in Parliament, many decisions have been made to support this region.

When I hear many complaints here now that there are still shortcomings in the regions, I ask myself: How have the member states dealt with the impulses we have sent out from the European level? How have they handled them?
