It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization cannot be the right approach.
The question now is whether the date of 214 or 218 is correct.
My colleague Mr. Rabke has presented a number of clever arguments that I don't need to repeat.

My request to the Commission is actually quite simple. Here, there is obviously a large majority in Parliament, across all the committees involved, in favor of affirming that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that in the matter of the deadline, one simply creates the necessary flexibility, which is certain to also create the possibility for the member states to implement it and that the burdens for the people, for jobs, and for economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that has been mentioned, which incidentally also contradicts the Commission's impact assessment, which also seems to be the case for 2018, was the argument that climate policy reasons could play a role here.
I want to emphasize this aspect once more: It makes no difference whether you burn foreign coal or your own coal when it comes to the issue of climate change.

My request to the Commissioner is to consider whether this four-year deadline might lead to the Parliament and, if such a new argument arises in the Council, whether it could not also enable the Commission to become more flexible.
I just understood the comment to mean that the committee is giving it some thought, and I thank you for that.

Mr President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner! If we must draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, held the presidency, it is that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.
We may have differing opinions on this matter, but if we Europeans speak with different voices, our influence will not be credible, and if we are not credible, other people will not follow us.
Why should you?

That is why I believe it is correct that the figures we decided on in late 2002 under Chancellor Merkel in 2007 under Chancellor Merkel must basically remain in place and form the basis of these negotiations.

I share your opinion that the ambitious 2-degree target should not be seriously questioned today for a significantly lower degree, because this makes the feasibility of these goals extraordinarily difficult and causes people to lose interest in them.
I have a great concern that we are questioning our intellectual property.
Our industry also invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we go ahead and loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes in it as they are right now, then we will actually be letting our valuable assets, our property, slip away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a point in investing in it, and that is why intellectual property must not be watered down.
As for the commitment, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible, and they must be feasible for these countries.
So we are doing the exact opposite of what we want, namely, you will be moving away from us.
Also appearing credibly in CancÃºn is an important point.
The really big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancun, I believe we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, it will yield nothing with the harvest.
Let's focus on the good land.
Mr President, Mr President! There was an incident during the debate on the European Council that I do not wish to address any further, because I was the target of an insult.
But I want to say that there are levels at which I cannot be offended, and where I do not even perceive it as an insult, because in order to offend me, one must have a certain level of seriousness.
However, I would like to express my heartfelt thanks for the countless signs of solidarity I have received since being here in this House.
I would like to express my heartfelt thanks to you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I think this is a sign of our shared democratic and pro-European conviction, which the overwhelming majority of this House shares.
For that, my heartfelt thanks.

Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr Gss, dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, I am delighted that we have now taken this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is being placed under direct European supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market, for strong control over a sector that has contributed to the crisis.
I would also like to make a comment on this, Mr. Vannier. The selection processes for the new authorities are underway, and the new authorities are only as good as the personnel.

I can only hope that in selecting the staff, the emphasis will truly be on expertise and independence from the financial industry they are supposed to control, on clear service to the public interest, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that override these important criteria.
In addition, there is still much to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still don't have proper transparency of the information that the rating agencies work with. We have far too much use of regulatory ratings in the financial industry and in the regulations that govern the financial industry.
We have serious conflicts of interest, we clearly have market power held by three major providers, and we have no liability for ratings created negligently.
Therefore, Commissioner, I would like to say that it is good that the consultation is underway, and we are eagerly awaiting the results.
I also think that civil society should participate in this consultation, but then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I am already looking forward to your proposal.
Be as courageous as you have been so far and let us work together to create legislation next year that truly solves the problems that still exist in the rating market on a European level.
We owe that to the citizens.
Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr Barnier, colleagues! The damage that credit rating agencies can cause has been evident in recent months since the beginning of this year.
There is therefore an urgent need for action.
That is why I welcome the directive, particularly the fact that ESMA will be given responsibility for the supervision and registration of credit rating agencies.
I think this is an important and good step forward.
However, numerous good and further-reaching proposals were lost during the negotiations on the report.
I would like to add the following here.
The appointment of ESMA therefore remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database for creating ratings have been dropped. There is also no mention of establishing a public rating agency.
The consistent and continuous review of established ratings by the supervisory authorities has also been overlooked.

The Commission had also proposed promoting unsolicited ratings in order to overcome the disastrous commissioned orders for the evaluation of financial market products. However, nothing has come of this either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the reports on this subject that are still to come, which Jean Paul Grosset and also you, Mr. Vannier, have spoken about.
Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I would also like to thank those who worked on this report, especially Mr Benson!
I want to point out two aspects and perhaps make you think a bit.
We agree that using energy efficiency in an energy-saving manner is the simplest and most sensible solution.
The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
I would like to ask the question: What has actually been achieved by repeatedly presenting new and higher percentage figures to the people in the parliament?
Have we really achieved more and moved more?
Or why and where has energy been used more sparingly?
I learn that the industry, which consumes a lot of energy, is becoming more energy-efficient because it saves money and because it is beneficial for them.
I'm learning that people will use more energy or less energy when they know about this device. So if they see it and can decide for themselves that it's beneficial, then they will choose it.
It's not the right way to call the method working with percentages, but the correct way to advance the method through incentives.
Second question: The Commissioner has just very impressively and clearly explained how complicated even just describing the term "What is it actually?" is.
How different is this in the member states?
The colleague just pointed out that the member states also have very different situations economically, geographically, and in every other way.
Is it the right answer to work with a number, to work with a binding number, or is there nothing else we can think of?

I believe that in energy policy, we need to move away from the debates of the past, which rely on simple numbers, binding targets, and so-called miracle solutions to think they can achieve something. Because obviously, we have not achieved enough.
Perhaps we should try the other way of differentiation, of different responses that accommodate different situational conditions, but also achieve an effect.
It's about the effects, not about how we feel.
This regulation, which is being discussed today, did not receive much attention in any of the committees for a long time.
But in the end, when the result was presented, some people in this house woke up.
Unfortunately, some have not appeared for the debate. It would have been very interesting to hear their opinions as well.
As a former member of the Convention, the spirit of the Convention is still very, very clear in my mind.
He has clearly called for the European Parliament to be given certain rights in many areas, in order to have and maintain its credibility within the institutions and towards the citizens.
In this sense, what the Convention laid down for us was still not a gift.
It was extremely difficult negotiations, especially led by the Belgian presidency vis-Ã -vis the Council, that enabled some important progress to be made.
I recall what my colleague Lehne said earlier: it was precisely the question of the constant possibility of checking whether the Commission has exceeded its powers.
Of course, there are some not entirely ideal regulations, such as international trade agreements, but I can still agree with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian presidency.
He really put a lot of effort into making sure something happened and our rapporteur, who negotiated with heart and mind.
13 I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a question that my colleague GÃ¶ran Ferm put to the Committee on Budgets on behalf of our group.
We did not reintroduce this amendment, but the Green Group reintroduced it with 40 signatures from the Green Member of Parliament.
We will abstain from voting on this motion.
I also discussed this with my Green Party colleagues and we are in complete agreement on the matter.
But I said that in general, we as a group are not submitting any new proposed amendments. We will abstain.

But I would like to explicitly state that we support this point on the financial transaction tax and hope that our colleagues on the other side of the House and in the votes in the coming days will support it.
I believe it is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
This is particularly important for cross-border services. Equal treatment is required here.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price limits were used to tax the crisis.
This is not acceptable, especially the financial insurance and trade industries, but energy is also heavily affected.
I hope that this will not also be used in the field of health services in the future.
I would also like to ask President OrbÃ¡n to review these regulations, because they are completely contrary to the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
At present, there is still no precise analysis of the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
There are also hardly any well-developed calculations and analyses available for the new proposals.
I may state that the EPP unreservedly affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
Unfortunately, considering reality also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for entirely different reasons or even deliberately misused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for general immigration in the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers do not get a chance to profit billions from people's fates by exploiting our asylum laws.
Asylum procedures must be carried out in a qualified and careful manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
That is why the Commission has provided for corresponding obligations in the new regulations.
I consider many of these to be correct, such as interpreters, proper health care, and consideration of special protection needs.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities of the member states are given far too few opportunities to combat abuse.
The possibility of conducting expedited procedures and border procedures should be unduly restricted.

If an applicant massively violates their cooperation obligations, there are hardly any possibilities for sanctions, quite the contrary. If they disappear illegally, the member state should no longer be able to terminate the procedure negatively. If they reappear, they should have an extended range of procedural options available to them.
Even in cases of obvious unfoundedness, an accelerated procedure should be possible after the second follow-up application.
This means significant cost increases.
The free legal advice in the form of a lawyer is currently also a significant increase in costs for the states, according to the wording of the Commission's draft.
I simply ask the Commission to reconsider the consequences of its proposals on practical reality, financial impacts, and the problems for the administrations of the Member States.
We want a high standard, but it must also be feasible and, above all, not set completely impossible tasks for particularly burdened member states.
Mr President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor once again briefly.
I have a big request for you, Commissioner FÃ¼le.
I want to start by saying that false assumptions lead to incorrect cost estimates.
We currently do not have declining numbers in the area of asylum seekers, but rather significantly increasing numbers.
This has to do with visa facilitations, for example, for Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently also experiencing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum rights in an attempt to enter a country in the European Union.

If one starts from the false assumption that disputing the first instance procedure in a higher-level reform would save costs in subsequent instances, one automatically assumes that all Member States have a poor first instance procedure.
But that is not the case.
If you raise the standards overall, it consequently means that this will lead to increased costs.
Raising quality standards for everyone and also complicating procedures, which I am happy to discuss, leads to higher costs in practical reality.
That is why I once again urgently request that the concerns of the LÃ¤nder be taken seriously, because the practical reports from the LÃ¤nder are, in part, of lasting value.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report commends the Commission for its successful competition policy.
However, it must not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and the growing gap between rich and poor.
Unfettered competition in the European Union still takes precedence over people's social needs.
The creed for free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are incapable of establishing social justice on a lasting basis.
A few proceedings for competition distortions and price agreements will not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time socially responsible internal market only works with strong and fair regulation.
More is urgently needed for this.
For example, it is not acceptable to always subject public services to private competition.
The report formulates recommendations for the Commission's future competition policy.
much stronger consumer protection, the removal of public services from competition rules, and the control of cartels. All of this is urgently needed.
Furthermore, it would be necessary to include a contractual clause for a secured social progress that is at least on par with the competition rules in Europe.
Mr. and Mrs., ladies and gentlemen, it is a truly important moment that we are commemorating the Holocaust of Oma and Sindi for the first time in the European Parliament today.
Let me begin with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy wrote to Robert Reinhardt in 1943 before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote: "I have found my parents again.
We are on the transport to the concentration camp.
I have mentally prepared myself to the point where I can endure death.
I would like to thank you once again for everything you have done for me.
Greetings to all, see you in heaven!
Your Robert!

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500 other Roma and Sinti. And although Roma and Sinti were among the first victims of mass industrial killings, along with Jews, 66 years later, the full truth about it remains unspoken.
And the complicity of mainstream society is often covered up.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be punished as a crime against humanity and recognized so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must fight against the prejudices against these people with passion.
We must stand united against racist abuse and violence, such as that which occurred in Hungary the year before last, and do so with civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not privileges for a select few, but the rights of all, because human and citizens' rights are indivisible.
Ladies and gentlemen, esteemed colleagues, in my view, the challenge now is to truly harness the potential of the law.
To push the boundaries of strong financial supervision in Europe, and we have doubts as to whether these possibilities are really being exploited institutionally.
We see in the procedure mix that we have not received the list of candidates in advance from the Parliament to this day, but only the final result.
It would be simple for you to send us the current ones for the executive directors.

We have clearly seen the lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions, and we have doubts about the process due to certain incidents, questioning whether the member states are truly appointing these institutions in the European interest.
And the other points in our letter justify asking a fundamental question.
But beyond that, it is of course about the suitability of the individual persons, and each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There, we see two major problems.

We have witnessed during the hearings that one of the candidates questioned the fact that it is a European institution, instead speaking of a network of supervisory authorities, and was not prepared to correct this even when asked.
When asked whether they are prepared to make all lobby contacts with the financial industry transparent, we did not receive any clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive responses to it.
Mr President, Mr President! We, as the Social Democratic Group, wish to table the same motion.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the distinguished House that we phrase it a bit more precisely.
We are dealing with a truly enormous influx.

Like any other country in the Mediterranean region, Italy is certainly overwhelmed by the current problem and cannot manage it alone. And Italy will not be the only country confronted with the massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain will also be confronted with this problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, we would like to request that we formulate the title of the debate very precisely, namely a statement by the Commission on immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other affected EU countries in coping with the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

The implementation of the regulation will ensure that, in the field of public transportation, firstly, a high level of protection comparable to that of other modes of transport is achieved for all passengers, including those with limited mobility.

Firstly, it achieves high levels of safety for people, secondly, it ensures a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly, it takes into account the special circumstances of a transport sector that is predominantly characterized by small and medium-sized enterprises.

This means that the extreme demands, which would have made bus services almost completely impossible due to excessive requirements, are off the table, as are demands where the majority of the member states would have fallen completely outside the scope of the regulation.
Bus transport services that benefit citizens in general must also offer a high quality of service to disabled people and those with reduced mobility.
They should have a right to assistance, and in the interests of social integration, this should be free of charge.
Madam President, I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Mr Kanzan, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of drafting a compromise on this challenging issue.
There were successes that have already been mentioned, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other technicalities that have already been discussed.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have covered passenger rights for all transport data.
The next necessary step is to create a common coherent and efficient framework program for all passengers.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU among European citizens.
In order to be credible, it is therefore essential to respect the coherence of rights for the different modes of transport.
There is no way around the fact that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of airplane passengers than, for example, to train tickets.

That is why it is particularly important when drafting a framework programme not to focus on the lowest and weakest standards, but rather to keep ambitious goals in mind, in the interests of the citizens.

Madam President, Mr. President, dear colleagues, we are in the midst of a major economic crisis. We have been talking about it for months, and it's all true. However, we usually only discuss it in headlines and then continue our work as if nothing had happened.
I believe it's because we, in Parliament, are not being specific or honest enough; instead, it's just headline politics that's going on.
What is actually being done to promote growth and stability?
Do we also contribute to managing finances more orderly and wisely?
Do we really critically examine whether we are making the right expenditures, or does each of us not have a new idea every day where more money can be spent?

If we do not have the strength to concentrate the financial resources on future projects, and that means conflict and debate and decisions, then there is no point in talking about innovation and research without making the necessary funds available.
That is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, we must also implement policies that stimulate the economy, rather than thinking all day long about how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We cheerfully continue to make decisions, constantly demanding new decisions today as well, which disrupt the economy in its development.
I would argue that the issue of binding energy efficiency targets is just one example of how contributing to this goal drives economic progress.
Do you really believe that our decisions, which we have often made in the context of energy, have stimulated the economy?
Or have we disturbed them?
I would like us to have a more honest conversation about this and then make a few fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that really move things forward.
It is more exhausting, it will also mean more hard work and more disputes, but that is the essence of democracy.
Mr. and Mrs. colleagues, the demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. Globalization opponents have been calling for such a tax for several years.
But even five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week it is on the agenda in the European Parliament, along with a CO2 tax and Eurobonds, and I think that's a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments that Annie Polimamata proposes in her report, and I think we will vote in favor of them accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
So far, the consolidation of public finances has focused solely on cutting spending.
The reduction in public spending primarily affects workers, pensioners, and the poor, i.e., those who rely on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
It is the second adjustment that can be made to consolidate public finances.
Above all, however, the revenue side also allows for the main contributors to the public debt crisis and the reduction of public debt to be adequately involved.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenues is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high level of public debt is primarily a result of the nationalization of private debt, namely the assumption of debts by private banks and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by the public sector.
The states are therefore by no means solely responsible for the debt crisis.
It is therefore not only logical, but also politically necessary, to ask the financial sector to contribute.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be held accountable as the main cause of public debt and would contribute to the reduction of this debt.
This is an important political signal sent out by this report, if it is adopted as it was presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens would increase as a result of Eurobonds are not acceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries also earn money through their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
Anyone who wants a social Europe, anyone who wants the EU to remain united in the future, must at least agree in principle to a transfer union.
Finally, I would like to say to the Commission that I hope you will finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been demanded for over a year now.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rescue umbrellas are meant to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they burden people with brutal austerity programs and let the perpetrators off scot-free. Furthermore, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Dear Hahn, it is absurd, and it brings tears to one's eyes, to hear this formal argument that none of this was meant to be socio-political.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the EU's responsibility. This policy of the Commission is in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
There is much to discuss, much to read about the rigidity of wages, which should be reduced.
That means to say: Wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, here blind people are talking about the color of humanity; those who formulate something like this have no idea about collective bargaining systems.
They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and reduce the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.

I want to make it clear that this Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, protect social dialogue, and prevent further erosion of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity measures. Thank you.
Barroso is a clever man, but he didn't answer my question.

That is why I am asking again: When Mr. Oettinger says, "We currently suspect that certain plants that are on the grid will not survive our stress tests," I interpret this to mean that you are aware that these plants are so poorly secured that they will not meet the criteria.
Why don't you take action today?
Because in my eyes, that is a real danger.
Mrs. Gabriele Zimmer has the floor. I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why they believe they need to present this topic with speech bubbles.
I believe it would be unhelpful if I were to state explicitly that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the Member States of the European Union and the European Union itself
must finally fully comply with its obligations for development aid and that it cannot in any way be tolerated that Member States are increasingly shirking this obligation.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still go hungry every day, and that most of them live in LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large portion of our development aid is not going towards the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but that this proportion has rapidly declined in recent years, with one billion people suffering from hunger.
And then talking about it. We hope that the LDC will be more shocked. I'm starting to think that's the case.
I urge you to address the problems in a concrete and clear manner and to assume concrete obligations in order to actually help the LDC.
In the context of the internal market, public procurement law and the awarding of public contracts are essential components.

Mr. Barnier, when you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, I have to ask: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
That is one of the basic rules that you, as you say, do not want to question yourself.

If one wants to protect basic rules, one must ensure in the future that elementary social standards are protected when awarding public contracts, that collective agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is prevented.
This is part of a modern, modernized public procurement law.
I expressly state that fundamental social rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe or we want a permanent conflict with the people who are turning away from this European Union, who do not see their interests safeguarded in it. Thank you.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner K. Cruz, radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and from a societal perspective.
That is why the Radio Spectrum Policy Programme is of particular importance.
Radio frequencies must be used efficiently, taking into account economic, social and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be fully utilized in all band areas to generate the highest possible efficiency.

The telecom package adopted last year must be based on radio frequency policy, because it also stipulates that the radio frequency management of the EU and its member states must equally meet cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be taken into account, especially when harmonizing the use of frequencies in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I is being carried out at very different speeds in the Member States.
Further opening of the UHF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experience gained from clearing this band.
Many technical and financial issues have not yet been conclusively resolved.

The issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities in the context of technical upgrades, for example in the area of wireless microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
When distributing frequency bands, the various interests must be weighed against each other responsibly.

On the one hand, the widespread provision of mobile broadband networks is a fundamental requirement in the interests of European citizens. At the same time, however, the development of public and private broadcasting must continue to be taken into account as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must set the right course for technological development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity.
Mr President, dear Mr Rehn, I would like to say first of all that you have described it: the situation has worsened.
The Eurozone is experiencing a widening gap between countries that are recovering and those that are weaker.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries are continuing to rise.

In this situation, I have a few questions for you. As Commissioner for Monetary Affairs, I ask you: On day 2 of the ECB system, liabilities and claims between central banks amounting to over 400 billion euros have accumulated.
This is because the banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities that are not provided for in the Eurosystem?
The big problem, why we are not making progress with the restructuring of the debt, is that the banking system, as Mrs. Ford also said, is not set up correctly.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present this?
And as Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, how do you assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then we saw, as we at GrÃ¼nE had predicted some time ago, that the measures taken against Greece and Portugal would not work as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone were not improved.
We still have rising, absolutely rising interest burdens macroeconomically for these countries.
We have seen increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
We still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, and from the strong Eurozone countries in particular.
And we have rising resource and food prices, at least if you take out the recent ups and downs.

In addition to the bailouts for these countries and the financial assistance, I wonder what measures are being taken to help the weaker countries manage their macroeconomic situation on these fronts, such as external demand and interest rate relief?
And how
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that improves the macroeconomic conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

In my view, the measures taken have, particularly in Greece, Portugal, and Spain, gone against the spirit of the EU treaty and have primarily affected the weakest members of society, while the strongest and wealthiest have so far not been required to bear any of the burden.
What measures are you taking to ensure that the wealthy are also called upon to contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Mr President, Mrs Gia GÃ¶nz is a Member of my group.
One can be against Feren Jorzani, one can be for Feren Jorzani.
One can reject Kingergg as a politician or be in favor of her.
This can certainly be determined freely and independently by anyone, regardless of whether they share a person's political beliefs or not.
The debate we are having here is about the last dictatorship in Europe.
we are taking you through one of the most brutal and bloodthirsty dictators to have existed on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that an elected democratic member of my group is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I believe that Parliament must also reject this, especially from the representative of a party that is known for its hatred and persecution of the Roma minority in Hungary, which is unparalleled in Europe.
If there is one person who has no right to criticize Mrs. KingerÃ¶nz, it is...
Mr President, my esteemed colleagues, dear visitors, the cultural diversity of Europe is an important asset that must be preserved and further developed in the future.
In order for this to be possible, we must address the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately two and a half percent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many other areas of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content offered by the cultural sector, just as the nature and quality of content have changed and evolved through technology.
We therefore need to create framework conditions for the cultural and creative industries in which they can develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and the creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
That is why we must also focus on this area in the field of school and vocational education.
We must impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
However, we must also strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural workers, not just their business competencies, but also their media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which artists can create culture and secure their livelihood.

to ensure the creative and cultural industries thrive in a digital environment in the future and to preserve Europe's cultural diversity and heritage as a key feature of the European Union.
Mr President, dear colleague Kelllam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues! Today we commemorate in a special way the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions are among the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was not only and, not least, called a century of expulsions for this reason, and not so unjustly.
Today, we all bow our heads in respect for the victims of these inhumane acts.
In this context, we demand a comprehensive investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism.

Modern Russia should not understand this as a political attack, but as support for the re-evaluation of its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is marked by both light and dark sides.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the following century.
We consider the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
The deportations in Europe reached a particular peak in the middle of the century under the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after World War II also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav War.
We must also not forget, however, that many colonial powers were characterized by displacement.
We must demand a serious examination of the various forms of displacement and the specious justifications for them.
This also includes clarifying guilt and punishing the guilty, insofar as it is still possible, as is currently the case in the Mlade trial.

But the crucial answer is European unity, especially through and with the self-governing Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the European unification process that has not yet been completed.
This historical task is something we owe not only to ourselves, but especially to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many politicians from all countries in Europe, from East and West, have worked on it.
Let us think, for example, of the Danzig declaration signed by Polish President Weisniewski and German Federal President Rau.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant, even towards the first signs of displacement, as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as sending the Arab immigrants back across the Mediterranean in boats, and we must resist when some want to abolish Europe's borderless achievements and bring back a new narrow-minded nationalism.
Let us bow our heads in Erfurt, above all in memory of the expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously commit ourselves to the continuation of European unity as the only real guarantee.
a policy that has brought so much misfortune to people in Europe over there in the last century. Never forget, Never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have lost none of their validity; they are best preserved in a united Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, I had the opportunity as a parliamentary election observer to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan, and I was impressed by the overwhelming support of the South Sudanese people to determine the future of their country themselves.
I also saw the great expectations among the people, who saw their country's independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands of so-called internally displaced persons, who were driven by the decades-long fighting in the south to the refugee camps in the north, set out on their journey to their former homes in southern Sweden.

Of course, in addition to the independence of their country, the people of South Sudan above all want to live in peace and pursue a path towards a happier future, after all the decades of conflict in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9, the new state of South Sudan is set to officially become independent and expand the family of nations in our world.
The state of affairs is appallingly bad, and much has already been said about this here.
Percentage of people live as nomadic herders, 80 are illiterate. The conflict over AbillÃ© is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also escalating, and according to observers' estimates, more than a thousand people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and mutilated are barely counted.
Sudan was already among the failed states.
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan is already beginning as a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that Europe has a great responsibility towards these regions.
Given the colonial past of the countries there, together with the UN and the African Union, this is where a common European foreign policy is needed, and it can also prove itself here.
This is not just about money, but also about supporting the fragile, emerging civil society.

We must negotiate hard with those who hold the fate of the country in their hands, namely the tribal leaders, the leaders of the military groups, so that they do not disappoint the hopes of their people in the country. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very grateful to my colleague Mr Bartolotti for having made Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament through his initiative to table this question.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now being discussed in Parliament from various perspectives, the Molkangolei and their situation have only received very little attention here.

It was, quite wrongly, Mongolia that, early on, took advantage of its independence as the starting point of the former communist blog and embarked on a path towards the democratization of its society.

As early as 1992, the Mongolians adopted a democratic constitution, and since then, several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, have generally had a democratic and correct course, which is far from being a matter of course for the states in this region.

The Mongolian government has been trying to combat corruption by law for several years and in 2010 imposed a moratorium on the death penalty, something that even some major democratic states have not managed to do to this day.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of a transformation process that is still ongoing.
Thus, a rural population that still lives predominantly in a nomadic fashion is crowding into the few cities that are not prepared for this in terms of infrastructure.
The country's mineral resources are not extracted in an environmentally damaging way.
Energy problems complicate civil and economic life.
Sandwiched between its large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia is at risk of becoming even more dependent on these countries than it already is.

Mongolia's efforts and successes - and here I see the glass as half full rather than half empty - in democratizing its society should be recognized as exemplary for the region and show what is possible despite a difficult past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only through aid programs, but also by the European Union being directly present in the Mongolian capital with its own
Representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolians and Europeans is not indifferent and that European interests will no longer be represented from a mission in Beijing. One more sentence, please.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues! After almost three years of intensive work, after far more than 3 amendments, after countless conversations and discussions,

After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, it is now up for a vote. The political package is a major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labeling of food products.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food products, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that's not all. The European food industry is also expected to benefit.
Legal certainty, reduced bureaucracy and better legislation are the goals.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it is important to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80% of SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must be suitable for every food and every non-alcoholic beverage, from staple foods to highly processed ready-made meals.
That is why mandatory labeling in traffic light colors is not possible, because this labeling is not suitable for staple foods.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political ideological differences in Parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise that has now been reached is still impressive.
Allergens will be recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is origin labeling for pork, poultry, lamb, and goat meat.

For other products, an impact assessment will determine whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example for milk and dairy products, single ingredients, i.e. products consisting of one main ingredient, meat in processed form.
Imitation products, etc. must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to molded meat and molded fish, which are composed of small pieces glued together.
Nor may packaging create the impression that something is inside that is not actually there.
If a picture of fruit is on a yogurt, there must also be fruit in it, not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients is always given per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be labeled, the date of the first freezing in meat and fish, and many other details.
But most importantly, all information must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have established a minimum font size, and we have tasked the Commission with setting binding rules for other factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we are protecting the craft industry at high costs and with bureaucracy.
Unpre-packaged fresh products must provide allergen information, but not the full nutritional information that can be determined through expensive analyses.

The Commission originally wanted this, but it would have destroyed our national and regional characteristics and specialties, it would have led to a European uniformity, and that's why we prevented it.
But now we have all reached an agreement, and the reputable consumer protectionists are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, in view of the current extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at the European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
This is the only way to restore the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report is about the strategy to prevent endless human suffering, resulting from approximately 35 deaths annually and over
5 million often severe injuries resulting from road traffic accidents, as well as the prevention of associated economic damage of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of deaths alone is equivalent to that which would be mourned in the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized commercial airplanes.
What wouldn't we do to prevent that?
The costs of accident consequences significantly exceed the annual total budget of the European Union.
That is why I am sure that it is appropriate for us to take sustainable action in this area.

Thanks to the constructive work of all shadow rapporteurs and many of my fellow Members, we have succeeded for the first time in this report to develop a holistic and coherent approach to improving road safety.
It takes into account the contents of the UN Road Safety Agenda 2010-2020 as well as the contents and objectives of the road safety work of the EU member states and broader civil society circles.
Firstly, it includes ambitious, yet realistic goals for the period up to 2020, and the SEERROM vision for the period beyond that.
By 2020, the number of accident fatalities must be reduced by 50%, the number of children killed by 60%, and the number of seriously injured individuals by 40%.
This is in the best interest of every individual among us, but also of our economy.
We recommend that the Member States break down the objectives and methods to their own territory and expect them to develop their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it specifies who is responsible for each activity and measure.
This is by no means just the European Union.

In the context of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that Member States, regional or local authorities, companies, and indeed every individual road user must take responsibility in line with their duty to contribute.
Thirdly, it specifies how, i.e., with which instruments, activities, and measures, the goals are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to do without guidelines, recommendations, and assignments.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity, which means that responsibilities and areas of competence have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

However, since you come from a wide variety of directorates-general, such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market, and others, you are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes you even contradict each other.
This is why we propose the appointment of a coordinator for road safety within the European Commission.
This sustainably avoids the establishment of a road safety agency, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data definitions and statistics.
We therefore call for, among other things, a harmonised analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as EU-wide data exchange while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main fields of action were identified.
They concern humans as road users, traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking, and the special consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request permission for tomorrow.

That's why the speed has to be reduced here.

Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the Council representative for the very clear description of the current situation.
We have constantly heard in this debate that it is about improving the situation for working women who have to decide for a child.
In my opinion, the directive focuses too much on increasing maternity protection to 20 weeks.
But do we really believe that the decision to have a child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity leave?

As a mother of three children, I am well aware that comprehensive concepts for services and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision to have a child and to establish equal opportunities for women.
The present draft guidelines do not do justice to the very good individual and overall offer concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that are tailored to the situation in the member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful thinking do not lead to a solution here.
That is why we must first develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
The comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children have the highest priority.
This can be ensured in different ways with different models.
Those who want to get somewhere by charging headfirst into a wall won't necessarily reach their destination faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors or build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution and provide more maternity protection to move forward here.

I believe that we really need to find an approach based on the Commission's draft directive, with more flexibility for different concepts in individual Member States, to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also protection for children in their first months of life.
This does not work with the draft that is before us today, which certainly did not have the broad majority support, as some colleagues have tried to make clear today.

I would like to see a bit more flexibility and a bit more realism here, and a bit of a better look at what the member states have already achieved today, without questioning our basic demands for that.
Madam President, Commissioner! I would like to make a few comments on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of putting a stop to tax evasion, which would be sensible, and instead of plugging loopholes for tax evaders, they have produced a Swiss cheese with large holes.
The planned transition period of five months gives tax evaders plenty of time to transfer money from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient to convert assets held in Switzerland into foundation assets.
The relevant forms are available at Swiss banks.
The tax authorities in Germany recently received information about several tax evaders who are hiding their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement grants these individuals an amnesty, and the tax investigators are no longer allowed to use the information they have.
What kind of agreement is this that ties the tax investigation to a chain?
A promotional video for Swiss banks states that, as a result of this agreement, customers will continue to benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial sector in the future.

This agreement is obviously lacking not only the necessary coordination at the EU level, but it also contradicts the EU's efforts to increase transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection in the member states more efficient, and above all to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, in our view, this cannot be acceptable.

Mr President, for years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at approximately the same level.
The EU's tasks have constantly expanded, and the financial requirements have increased significantly.
Thus, necessary new institutions have been created for financial market supervision.
However, in order for these institutions to effectively carry out their tasks, they need to be well-funded.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become undeniable.
To strengthen the economy of these countries, a comprehensive economic stimulus program would be necessary.
Some experts even speak of the need for a Marshall Plan for the crisis-ridden EU countries.
The EU does not need austerity programs that destroy growth, but rather a growth-promoting spending program that secures jobs and income for workers and young people in the EU.
But what is the Council doing in this situation?
It shortens the Commission proposal, which already falls far short of what is needed.

If a reasonable increase in the budget is not feasible in the current political climate, then Parliament and the Commission should do everything in their power to at least prevent the cuts proposed by the Council.
This is a more difficult task. Ladies and gentlemen, it is precisely in times of crisis that it becomes apparent what kind of European Union we really want.

Do we want a Union in which KiIT actually also plays a role as a link? We say that it is not indifferent to us whether people have to live in poverty in any country that is a member state of the European Union?
Let us meet in our shared responsibility to fight against poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we opt for a union as outlined by colleagues from the far-right group in this Parliament?

Sometimes I believe that, with the attitude of the member states and especially some of the governments of these member states, we are dangerously close to this vision of a European Union as formulated by the right-wing extremists.
just don't do anything together, don't use any common tools, don't set any common indicators, use vague wording wherever possible.
The Derden report makes this very, very clear on many issues, and I believe we need to become much stronger in this area.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sell-off of public assets, the sell-off of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
With winter approaching, it cannot happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death because of rising energy prices.
Here we share a common responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
We must stand up for that, not for the nationalist nonsense we've heard from the right.

What advice would we have given to our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, when there was a depression, when the financial markets had already undermined the democracies and when they were heading towards war?
I think two things would be necessary - two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you need to do quickly. Don't let yourself be slowed down. Regulate every product, every institution, and every player like that!
Merkel said, "But a transitional government alone that enforces the fiscal emergency program cannot have a future if there is no democratic emergency program."
And that means, of course, that we need a European community, of course we need other treaties, of course we need a system that works, but that only gains legitimacy through referendums.

And we need to start campaigning now because the situation has become so dramatic that a complete change of thinking is necessary before the right-wingers, before the national whiners, regain control over something that was already built up.
Thank you, Madam President. There is no doubt that this House is committed to transparency and openness towards the citizens.
Of course, my EPP group does that too.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual goal.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are being ignored. The protection of competitive processes, sensitive and personal data is being disregarded.
This is a massive violation of data protection, which we otherwise always advocate for.
Should we now give up the privacy of the world public?
This is precisely the danger with the present report, because administrative procedures and decisions, which also include personnel issues for example, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information in the context of approval procedures, court proceedings and competition proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, and overly broad definitions, the report allows public access to such documents as well. This is because a document is defined as any data or content that is in any way related to the policies, measures, and decisions of all EU bodies and institutions.
This also largely includes preparatory, confidential and secret documents, as well as all related information.
Thus, this definition encompasses not only documents, but also information.

Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with such an important and relevant topic as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always a great risk that in the end you are left with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to incorporate their two or three preferred topics.
If you look at the result that will be put to a vote tomorrow, you can undoubtedly congratulate our rapporteur Matthieu Grosch.

He has managed to develop a good, coherent and manageable result from several hundred proposed amendments, which sets the main priorities for transport in the future on safety, environmental protection, energy and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that such important issues as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are adequately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in view of the impending shortage of skilled workers in the transport sector, which must be actively addressed if bottlenecks in well-trained professionals are to be prevented in the future.
Further opening up of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
The safety on our roads is an issue that we must continue to address in the future.
I have a more critical view of other points.
That's how I would have liked a statement on the model ship, where more traffic would be shifted from the road to the rail and waterways.
For this reason, I believe the discussion about the Gigaliner is not the best solution for more sustainability.
The further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport should also be critically observed and reconsidered.
There are still technical harmonizations and fair competitive conditions to be resolved here.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, it amazes me that we always have to remind ourselves what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union, and it is defined to serve the strengthening of economic and social cohesion within the community, while particularly promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been proven, especially in the years of the crisis.
In many regions, the economic development would look much more difficult without these funds.
The implementation of the structure of funding is based on operational programmes, as previously mentioned, in which the funding strategy of the respective region is described.
The European Union, member states, and regions are working together in partnership here, thereby creating genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy is also based on the reliability of the programmes and the funds made available and allocated.

That is why I am very surprised when Member States, as well as the Commission, as we are now seeing, repeatedly attempt to use Structural Fund resources like a piggy bank for all sorts of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the meaning and purpose of cohesion policy and, moreover, creates uncertainty for the actors in the regions who are already working on achieving the goals on the basis of long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important goals.

However, this will only be achieved if the partnership-based cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and the actors in the regions are involved and remain involved.
Because only you have the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the genuine partnership and solidarity link between the various policy levels in the European Union.
It makes the solidarity of Europe visible on the ground in the regions, and it should not be abandoned lightly due to political quick fixes.

When a change was called for in the 2009 regulation on biometric passports, to conduct a review after three years and submit four studies, our group supported it.
And this was also because she had repeatedly raised major concerns for data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the benefits of biometric data in travel passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this method, and the resulting underestimation of other links in the security chain are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this major misconception, namely the assumption that they are unchangeable and most trustworthy.
And that is, in fact, not the case.
These data are also modifiable in the course of life.
In children, it looks different than in old age.
And that is also why reliable and serious studies and the conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues apace.
we have now been able to determine.
Incidents in Great Britain and in other countries repeatedly prove that the chips are not at all secure against misuse.
They are broken cheerfully and can cause lasting damage to those affected.
Standards within the EU are also extraordinarily diverse.
The error rate is very, very high, just like in France and the Netherlands.
And time and again, the question must be asked: what good are biometric data to us if documents are being forged and are in circulation?
So if a link in the chain is forged, the original documents are inconsistent, biometric data would not be of any help to us.
The Chaos Computer Club in Germany needed only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

To do this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a second-hand adhesive, a digital camera, and a bit of wood glue. In just a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. That's all there is to the supposed security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies and, of course, also the results and the consequences that can be derived from them.

Figures sometimes speak louder than big words, and to date, the European Parliament - you also mentioned this - and the European Patent Office have granted nearly 2,200 patents for plants and almost 1,200 patents for animals, which were developed with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I would like to mention two outstanding examples: the approval of patents for genetically modified and selectively bred barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Our farmers, our brewers, and we as consumers are all affected.
In my opinion, this example demonstrates a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example: do not confuse the so-called LongLiToate with their LongLi oil, which you have in the engines of your diesel engines.
This patent was granted in violation of the valid EU rules, thanks to a trick employed by the US corporation Arcadia, which applied for it.
It is not the tomato that has been patented, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This shows the way Drexel works, and this despite the fact that, as she says, Commissioner, it is clearly stated in Article 4 of the 1998 Biopatent Directive that plant varieties and animal breeds A and B are not patentable, as they essentially involve biological processes for the breeding of plants or animals.
We believe that this definition needs to be clarified, it needs to be precisely interpreted.
Technical procedures that are used to support conventional search should not lead to patentability overall.
We specifically do not patent life.
We need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with creation, once again against the patentability of life throughout Europe.
Because, Commissioner, we are calling for a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and will remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear stance on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive: no patents on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, we demand a clear establishment of the breeder and farmer privilege throughout all legislation. Thank you.
