But if these positions are not filled soon, we would have to consider cutting funds, and that would be bad for Orrius.
I still recommend stress relief, thank you
Madam President, most esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what should worry and alarm us is not just the sheer number of unemployed young people in Europe, but the trend.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of unemployed young people increased by 26.5 percent, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the job market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that young people are turning away from this EU because they have no reasonable work and life prospects.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure that decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already recognize some progress, but please make sure that the long-standing mental lull does not now turn into operational panic!

When I read that the Commission is launching a program to provide financial support to young people who apply abroad, I realize that we are organizing a traveling circle that does not solve the problem.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive. Technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff are then lured away from the states that are wealthier and not in this crisis.
In this crisis, the cause of this development requires offensive measures, namely the reduction of this austerity that is holding back the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
By combining it with European funding, it would then be possible to actually develop an integrated concept that creates a life perspective for young people.
Lastly, this youth unemployment situation is also incompatible with the nonsense of wanting to raise the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy that gives young people access to the job market.
Therefore, I urgently ask for your thanks.
Colleague, you said that everything that would speak in favour of the financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you came up with very speculative examples yourself.

I would like to know from you what you think, in light of what you have said, about these investigations by the Commission and the Commission's study, which very clearly states that, up to now, the real economy has been far too little considered in its dependence on...

to the financial markets that 95 percent of companies are by no means dependent on borrowing money and that one can indeed turn a negative growth effect, which has been discussed so far, into a positive one by making corresponding growth-promoting public investments
is that just speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded, broad-based study by the commission also has its justification and constitutes a strong argument?

Mr. and Mrs. colleagues, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been under discussion for many years. However, I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She is at least open to the idea of taxing the financial markets and, above all, making them bear the costs of the crisis.
I think that is a very important signal to the financial markets.
But this is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.

In a number of member countries, there were a variety of actions, petitions, and written initiatives aimed at convincing politicians to finally implement a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I think that Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that has voted in favor of this report for this tax.
Certainly, it is not enough to stabilize and limit the financial markets as much as might be necessary. But I think it is a truly important step that has been taken.
I would like to expressly appeal to the council to take the voices of the citizens and voters seriously and to work towards this goal.
that there will be a real introduction, that it will not be blocked in the Council, due to the British position or other positions, the introduction of this tax.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It is now up to the Council to take action, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this control is actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.

Dear female colleagues and dear male colleagues, I think that despite all the detailed problems that can be discussed and should be discussed in the further legislative process, we should be pleased about one thing.
This is clear. Financial markets cannot function according to this model. When everything goes well, the banks pocket the profits, and when something goes wrong, the taxpayers foot the bill.
That is why it makes sense to subject financial transactions to a tax as well.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we will not have upheavals, but rather we will make a lasting contribution to achieving a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for, namely that companies

Having access to capital means that savers have the opportunity to put something aside or set it aside for retirement, and that the financial markets once again fulfill the purpose for which they were created, namely to provide added value for the real economy.
What drove us into the financial crisis were products that created no value for the real economy.

That is why it makes sense to introduce a tax, a contribution to ensuring that this is heavily punished, that it is sanctioned, that it is controlled, in the sense that capital once again fulfills its purpose.
that is why I am advocating for this proposal today with a large majority
The reform of the general preferential system was indeed necessary.
It is good now that there are longer maturities and that there is more security for export credits.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has already pointed out.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to World Bank classifications.
In the past, Parliament has repeatedly expressed strong criticism of the gross domestic product as the sole criterion.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with 4 or up to 12 times the gross domestic product.
So that is a huge and far too wide a range, and it does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
We certainly do not find it objectionable that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait find out about flying.
The reform in this regard was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China, on the other hand, are countries with upper-middle incomes. We certainly don't have to worry about them falling out of the APS either.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Up until now, the Commission had at least also used the vulnerability criterion, i.e., countries that export little or only very few goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on exports and are very vulnerable from being rated too high.
Why, then, did the Commission highlight this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji, Gabon, and Botswana, for example, will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why didn't the Commission continue with the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate anyway?
There is a growing suspicion that the Commission wants to force poorer countries into unfavorable free trade agreements.

The preference system, however, is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays any role at all.
However, there may still be an opportunity for our colleagues in the plenary to agree to our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
However, the new regulations also lead to trade regions being torn apart.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should focus more on developing regions rather than individual countries.
Here too, we Greens have submitted an amendment, which we hope will receive a lot of support.
It is also problematic when countries that have benefited from the APS until yesterday are suddenly dropped from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and we see in our own countries that a few months are not enough for economic development.

Ultimately, however, we Members of Parliament must also consider whether we want to focus solely on speed for all legislative initiatives and then work with lopsided compromises, or whether we would rather involve the entire plenary.

I believe that for legislation, the entire parliament is important for democracy, and it is not the time or the speed that is important, but rather it takes time and democracy to enforce and properly pass laws.

Mr President, High Representative, I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to witness the great hope and expectations for a better future that people had as they stood and waited at the polling stations to cast their votes.
We know today that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were not fair or democratic.
We need to address this issue head-on, as my colleague Nidelschewa has done in her report.
Last year's president, Josef Kabila, has declared himself the winner of the election. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again. It is unclear whether third countries like Rwanda are involved.
The civilian population is the one that suffers in every case, and has not been able to live in peace and quiet for decades now.
The country's wealth is squandered in a web of corruption. In all international rankings, the Congo remains in one of the last places.

The international community, particularly the European Union with its capabilities, must increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow real democracies into the country. He has the opportunity to do so in the upcoming regional elections.
and that the Congolese army does not harass the civilian population, but finally takes international fugitives for crimes against humanity like Bosco and Ganga and brings them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to not delivering any more weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Mr. and Mrs. colleagues, the TuPEC is intended to create additional enforcement rights against crisis countries in the Eurozone.
The European Semester, which was established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be strengthened.
According to the Commission's wishes, Member States should be forced to accept financial aid.
The Six Pack has already established extensive sanctioning possibilities that can be imposed on Eurozone countries with financial problems.
The European Semester is already being perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a sensible economic policy coordination instrument.
At the same time, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone if they make the wrong choice in the election on Sunday.
Why don't we stop with these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically escalatedâI am thinking of Spain, of Cyprusâit is not helpful to publicly shame the member states that are in crisis.
We should finally develop solutions. The rapporteurs of the TuPEEC have indeed developed some very sensible approaches to this end.
Elisa Ferreira did indeed mention the Tilbungsfonds. This would be a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
But I also agree with John Paul Goess's proposal for an orderly state bankruptcy.
but it is that Europe makes a joint and solidaric effort to put the Eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop being complacent and pointing fingers at their partner countries.
They need to start doing their homework, invest in growth, and take responsibility.
Merkel's one-sided austerity policy has simply failed as a solution to the crisis.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in June 2010, the EU heads of government finally realised that the European Community needs a better coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is indeed entirely correct that members of an economic and monetary union cannot solely focus on how their policies affect businesses, workers, and consumers in their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
An internal market without coordination in economic wages and social policy presents a great temptation for member states to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can economically and politically turn the monetary union into a crime.
And that is exactly the situation the EU is currently facing.

The German economy has been draining the lifeblood from its neighbors for years, failing to stimulate growth through investment and wage increases. Instead, Berlin has brought the Eurozone to the brink of ruin with a decade of aggressive export policies.
It is therefore encouraging that the Commission is slowly getting to grips with this core problem of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and is making corresponding suggestions.

The Federal Republic is rightly called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare. The Commission is also right to demand an end to the abuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a later, but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner, Mr. Rehn, that you will vigorously advocate these demands to the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start by expressing my thanks to the Commission, particularly to Commissioner Barnier, for a very simple reason: the experience from the last legislative period, before 2009,

That was, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal for the European Private Company was put forward by Mr. Commissioner Barnier's predecessor, Mr. Commissioner Merkli, who essentially put company law to sleep. We in these five years have been neglecting this important issue, which is significant for the internal market.
have progressed.
Fortunately, that has fundamentally changed.

In the meantime, there are a variety of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has been working on the issue of further developing company law. We now have a brand new consultation, which we in Parliament are naturally also dealing with.

The Committee on Legal Affairs has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, would also be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the method of an oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make clear in a subsequent resolution our position as Parliament on what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary to develop a new action plan for European company law, similar to the one we had about ten years ago, and for many reasons.
There are gaps within European company law - literal gaps - which essentially mean that the single market is not complete.
I want to mention the example of the absence of the 14th directive on seat relocation, which is usually a very typical example of such a gap.
Parliament has twice called in legislative initiative reports for the European Commission to come up with concrete proposals on this matter.
There is also the expert panel, which the European Commission itself appointed, and he also held the same opinion on this matter.
It is simply one of the fundamental freedoms in the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market with regard to its registered office.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

However, against this backdrop, I must also criticize the fact that the European Commission's position to date on the 14th Directive falls well short of Parliament's expectations and, in our opinion, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are confident that in the course of further work, if it comes to an action plan, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan after all.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the further development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens for companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the topic of
Accounting But I also believe there is more to be done and there are further aspects that will be clarified during the consultation.
We are also expecting further proposals from the Commission here.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the issue of the European Private Company, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If individual member states - let me say this from my own perspective - if there are individual member states in the EU that are not able to break the deadlock on their own due to a lack of decision-making power.

If we want to move Europe forward, then we must consider using the instrument of enhanced cooperation, as we have done with other initiatives such as patents and family law, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the Commission to give this issue some more thought.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, i.e. a kind of Rome regulation for cross-border problems in company law.
I also believe that this issue requires further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the Commission to do so.
This is also closely related.
The insolvency law, but it has already been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You can see that there is a lot of work to be done in the area of corporate law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative here and it is clear that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can also represent progress in shaping the internal market.
Parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
We will certainly discuss the details, of course, and we will have to do that.
But for that, too, a big thank you to the Commission.
Of course, we would be delighted if the Commission were to actually take up our initiatives and turn the concrete proposals into reality.
Dear Commissioner, I greatly appreciate your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But you cut a deal with Mrs. Merkel on the minimum wage, and I don't believe you about the question of job creation in the healthcare sector.
How is new work supposed to be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How can employment in the healthcare sector grow if the Commission, in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, is asking some Member States to further reduce their healthcare spending?
I fear this point in this plan is merely announcement politics, not a real initiative for new jobs.
On the contrary, due to austerity measures, there is already a shortage of medical supplies and medications, not just in Greece.
I think that those who constantly deploy new bailouts for banks must now focus on a bailout for the people, especially on ensuring medical care in the crisis countries.
The sentiment among countless pro-Europeans like myself is one of frightened horror at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is, after all, encouraging that it is now being stated much more clearly what we are dealing with and that Italy is not being ignored either.

You know for yourself that we are stuck in a number of traps, not only in the debt and growth trap, but also in the trust trap and in the power trap, esteemed Commission, and also addressed to the Council.
Unfortunately, they have so far neglected to actually address the central issue of the separation of the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here is repeatedly evaluated in expert opinions, as no serious limits have been set on shadow banking.
Furthermore, we are dealing with systemic risks. The issue of "too big to fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little need to say anything about the rating agencies.
As you prepare for the Council summit, I can only urge you to advise him to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing the issue of power between the real economy and the financial sector.
In short, you must finally work credibly before the Europeans to ensure that banks are brought under control and that citizens are not always forced to bear the burden.
However, one can still leave the country that has rejected the euro, primarily because one wants to retain the flexibility of devaluation, especially for socio-political reasons.
In light of the experiences you have now had in Sweden, would you recommend that the Greeks also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively use this socio-political instrument of devaluation?
Thank you, Mr President! I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environment Committee with a two-thirds majority, with 62 votes in favor, no votes against, and no abstentions.

And of course, the top priority in these legislative procedures must be a high level of protection, a high level of consumer protection, especially for the most vulnerable members of our society, for children who need protection.

If you take a look around, I have two children of this age, and considering the prevalence of allergies and intolerances there, I believe we were in the right place.

Thank you very much! A report about a traffic accident over the weekend involving an HGV driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into the ditch has once again confirmed to me how necessary...
clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest periods and their monitoring by means of the digital tachograph is important for us for road safety, but also for the people affected themselves.
The digital roofograph represents a certain innovation. It has new problems, but also old ones.
The new problems arise from new manipulation possibilities, which we also need to control technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the monitoring or lack of monitoring in various member states.
In my view, what we are now regulating anew must take into account, first and foremost, that not every time when no journey is recorded automatically results in a rest period.
Because many drivers have to load and unload, and this is of course also to be considered as working time.
The second problem is that the speed records from the file were removed.
I think that's wrong, because there are also major accident risks here.
We also want to have weight sensors, and we also want to have a hotline for reporting fraud, which is anonymous and can be traced.
What I will also be bringing forward is a motion that animal transport control be included in this regulation.
I think this is important because it is also a central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have any lasting disabilities if professional medical help had been provided quickly enough after their accident, that is, within the first so-called "golden hour".
We would be a significant step closer to Vision Zero.
Now the Eko system, which we are discussing today, cannot prevent accidents. It also does not absolve one of the duty to provide first aid.
It is only used to automatically inform an emergency response center in the event of a serious accident.
It must also establish linguistic contact with the accident vehicle to prevent abuse and overloading due to traffic accidents.
If the emergency call is confirmed or no one responds, emergency doctors equipped with a few but crucial pieces of information are sent to the accident site.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies with the member states.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the ecosystem remains dormant, meaning it does not send any signals or data and cannot be located.
From a data protection perspective, it is therefore far superior to a mobile phone.
The system becomes active with the automatic basin filling controlled by sensors or the deliberate manual triggering.
It then sends an agreed-upon minimum set of information to an emergency operations center.
Europe-wide uniform standards and specifications will ensure that this data is recognized, evaluated, and handled upon arrival as an emergency call.
Therefore, the member states must also upgrade and expand their emergency medical service chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency system to be based on the EU-wide emergency number 112, to be free of charge for users, to work throughout the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency systems of neighbouring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
Other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or availability of parking spaces, can also be offered through these systems at a later date.
In recognition of the automotive industry's outstanding achievements in providing private emergency call systems, these should retain their legitimacy alongside the public system.
Users can also choose such a system based on comprehensive information.
This may be accompanied by costs, if applicable.
Temporary use of data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services or other service providers.
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem we've created for ourselves today.

Because if this brewery or the beverage retailer is 107 kilos away from my home, I no longer have a chance that they will continue to offer me their goods in the future, without having to buy a new tachograph, without new bureaucracy.

That is why, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today, because I believe that we should not impose too much on our small and medium-sized entrepreneurs. There were many points that we were able to include, which were positive!
It was actually planned to only accept fifty kilometers within the radius of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd of the EU Commission.
a little 100 kilometers yes just barely perhaps feasible
what if it goes beyond that

because, for example, the person who supplies goods for the construction or for the beverages for the breweries is completely monitored throughout the entire working day via GPS.
For these reasons, and also for data protection reasons, I consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable, and I would like to reiterate why I voted against it.
Thank you very much for this question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision.
I waited for the approval of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we were still in the process of asking the necessary questions about legal certainty regarding ACTA.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
That's not what you wanted. It's now obvious that the ECJ is being used to delay things. That's clear.
Why did I say that there is a wide margin of interpretation?

because one can read and interpret anything into these broad formulations, such as Internet surveillance, auxiliary police, and ISPs.
And that means legal uncertainty, legal uncertainty is also not helpful for our economy, dear colleague!
Mr. Leichtpreter, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
Or are you completely against the rejection of any intellectual property?
How do you envision the E-Commerce Directive being adapted to modern conditions in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject any debate on these issues and do not stand for intellectual property.
Is that true or what?
Mr. Speaker, it is becoming clear that this is not just about individual facts that we need to discuss, but about the fundamental question: How do we stand with democracy and civil liberties?
And if we look at ACTA, we see that it is in a way symbolic for a lack of transparency, for a lack of democracy, for the violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.
and came about in an undemocratic manner, because the free use of the Internet simply would no longer be possible, and neither would the freedom to use generics to the same extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and have already voted against ACTA.
Yes, ACTA has been voted on in the streets, on the Internet, and in relation to the Committee on Petitions in many countries, not just within the EU.
Even outside the EU, I believe we must not ignore this vote. This is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who elected us.
I can only tell you: put ACTA in the files, that would be decent.

Madam President of the Council, as rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have completed two procedures under your presidency: the Financial Regulation, which provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been pending in the Council, and you have brought this process to a close based on the results of the Polish presidency.
I would therefore like to thank you for two truly very committed financial officers who have worked on these files and also reached out to the ambassadors.
They will be missed. His efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
They have truly earned themselves a reputation for looking after the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here now as a representative of my group and would like to support my colleague Mr Fehlner's motion.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This requires careful handling of the issue of intellectual property rights.
In order to clarify the outstanding issues, the European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an opinion.
I believe that respect for the highest court of the European Union alone demands that we wait for this decision.
There is objectively no reason at all to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it once the Court has presented its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that will then be made will take place in a different consciousness and a different awareness than today.
I don't mean to say that the wrong-way drivers on InternetautoBaden should determine our policy. That's why I ask you to support this motion.
As always, when colleague Turmes speaks, he is very wise, and one would wish that what he says had much more influence on European politics.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a good idea, but only if they are sustainable and if the necessary political foundations are established.
We run the risk of insuring against guarantees that we do not have under political control.

A necessary energy transition in Germany: 8,380 kilometers of grid network would be required, but only 100 kilometers of these corresponding high-voltage transmission lines have been built, because it also faces resistance from citizens, including very environmentally-oriented citizens.
We need to come up with something from politics.

One idea would be to create shared corridors for power lines, combining not only high-speed rail lines and broadband networks, but perhaps also constructing power lines alongside the highways above them.
However, this requires a much more comprehensive plan than has been provided so far, but I would like to at least suggest it at this point.

Mr. and Mrs. colleagues, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. However, I am also aware that the borders of a country have always been and will always be a very sensitive issue for our member states.
I am aware that the problems between the member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And there are various problems.
And by ignoring them, you don't make the problems better, and you don't solve them better either.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and it would never occur to anyone here to want to close the border again just because we are having problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, not for restrictions and reprimands.
The veil investigation was established because we want to ensure security while also allowing freedom of travel.

If we carry out undercover operations successfully, I assume that this will also be the case at the borders with the Czech Republic, where one or two drug dealers are involved in more than just a few cases, but in...
F try to gain access. Then I think it would be good if the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech Interior Minister work together to solve the problems at the border.
And the Commission should not regulate this, but rather act positively and supportively.

We want to put the populists in their place, but we need to solve the problems with each other. That is why I am also asking the Council to work together with Parliament to find a solution so that we can successfully pass the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of travel and at the same time ensure the security of citizens.
The cases of disproportionate border controls that the Parliament lists in its question also show why the Council actually wants to exclude the Parliament from Schengen.
The Council wants to continue undermining freedom of travel without involving Parliament or without any form of parliamentary control, without any form of public scrutiny.
I can understand why you prefer to pat each other on the back in back rooms, away from uncomfortable questions.
No wonder the German government wants to rule out any evaluation of internal borders and thus does not want to look at how much freedom of travel is being restricted.
However, Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe and therefore also to the European Parliament. Thank you very much!

Dear Mr President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christof! It is a special moment for me today and for my group to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
We are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person is at the helm of the EU whom we consider part of our political family.
You are taking over the presidency at a time when the European Union is facing enormous challenges, and it is necessary to set the course for whether the
Will the Union actually have a future, or will it prove itself to be a footnote in history, which in my view would be a historic defeat.
After the discussions we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairmen of the parliamentary groups and parties in your country, I know that they are counting on
We have prepared excellently for our presidency and that you are also aware of the far-reaching implications of your task.
But you have also made it clear today that you want to deliberately draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of people.
I can tell you here that after all I have heard in recent years, this is the first time that a President of the European Union has done exactly that and announced and said this

I have missed that for a long time in official speeches. What is being said is: This is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for us being in this crisis, but who have to bear the greatest burdens.
It is difficult to implement this approach exactly.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and I am quite certain that you will do this, if you primarily encourage people with your presidency and in the way that you do.
They exercise their rights and contribute to ensuring that the Council and the European institutions are aware of this very task.
We keep talking about the euro and its stability, about the necessity, which I also see, that they are important for the functioning of the European Union and for the Eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which were defined.
It can never be the goal of the European Union to accept that people in the European Union must go hungry, that health systems collapse, that municipal administrations have to cease their work.
She twisted something.
It is not what we refer to as the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that social cohesion must be about solidarity between individual member states, but also between the most diverse population groups.
The European Union must not allow itself to be used repeatedly as an instrument or spokesperson for a specific segment of the population, nor should it present itself in this way.

One final point I would like to address, of course, to emphasize that everything you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us and that we will support the points that go in this direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
I think that some decisions in recent weeks and months, particularly in the elections in Greece and the referendum votes in Ireland, were also driven by fear.
And if the rulers in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Best of luck with your work.
Dear colleagues, I believe that we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs.
Mr. Colleague, it will be very, very important to work on this dossier quickly and reliably in the coming weeks and months.

The eyes of the world are currently on us and on the Council, waiting to see if we will take this step, to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step towards European integration, and for me, through a European banking union.
It should be noted that the Parliament demanded this with a broad majority two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been necessary.
Additional billions in bills have been generated as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the necessary conclusions and wants to take this step to further deepen the Eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has drawn up the proposals so quickly.
However, there are some difficulties associated with the Council's decision that the ECB should become the eurozone's supervisor.
In the Council, this leads to unanimity and means that Parliament does not have codecision powers on this issue.
Based on the experience with the supervisory package, this is not acceptable.

That is why it is important that we work quickly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal on changes to the ECB together with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, and in doing so, effectively establish the principle of democratic participation by Parliament.
Democracies also face additional challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If you become responsible for banking supervision now, Parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, the right to ask questions, the right to appoint, and I am sure that Parliament will fight for these rights in a broad majority.

We will have to thoroughly regulate the complicated issues in the coming weeks, including those related to the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility. Thank you.
By proposing to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to push these countries into free trade agreements.

These are not free trade agreements, as the term "economic partnerships" suggests, but are solely concerned with the interests of the EU and not with the development interests of the partner countries.
This is completely contrary to the EU's goal of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments towards this objective.
Countries such as Cameroon, Ivory Coast, and Namibia would be severely affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects such as those in Southeast Africa would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
The South-South cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and only mean that other countries should kindly buy our goods.
If the Commission really believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The development committee of this house has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
we should support this in the plenary session.
Mr.! There are an enormous number of human rights problems in Central America as well as in Peru and Colombia.
And we, as EU representatives, cannot simply close our eyes to this.
We will thoroughly examine the roadmap for human rights required by the EP in the case of Colombia and Peru, once it is drawn up.
It must have substance and be binding, and include initial results, such as the conviction of criminals and the safe return of displaced persons to their land.
And of course it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.
We Greens believe it is right that the Trade Committee is demanding environmental and social standards in the proposed regulation on safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The Trilogue must then confirm these, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
In fact, the EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.

That is why we also demand that the Greens conduct a proper impact assessment before every negotiation, one that not only examines the economic consequences for the EU, but also the impact on human rights.
Mr Barroso, I made it clear in the first round what I wanted to focus on.
I am concerned with my group's expectation of the Commission to once again fulfill its responsibility within the relevant bodies, the Troika, in order to make it clear.

The Commission, as a European institution, stands for ensuring that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not shortened, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
That is your task.

If we succeed in making this clear, we will also be sending a signal to the people who are protesting by the thousands and hundreds of thousands these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we, as a group, also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
I heard the news this morning that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we ended up, where people in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help and support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here we must finally take action.
I'll add one more thing: An approach that is in the minds of many decision-makers is that the people in Greece and in other countries have been living beyond their means.
We must be punished for it today and endure sanctions.
It is unfit to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not suggesting that to you, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is also prevalent in many countries and, unfortunately, is also repeatedly present in my own approach, for example.
Chairman, I confess, I made a terrible mistake
I would like to make a statement not on this report, but on the Morera report on the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I would then ask to be called up again.

Madam President! The new directive creates a basis for dealing with books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and TV productions that are protected by copyright, but for which the rights holder cannot be identified, identified, or located.
According to this, book films, photos or other intellectual creations for which no rights holder can be found should also be made available to the public.
And thus a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us on the Culture Committee, it was particularly important to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the European Union's cultural heritage in this legislative initiative.

Our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting organizations have countless unpublished works in their archives, and up until now, they have not been made available simply because the rights holders are unknown.
That changes with the directive.
In the future, it will enable the use of this cultural asset, provided that a thorough search is carried out prior to publication.
This is a very important point, so that it is not said lightly: We cannot find the rights holders.
Because a balance had to be found between the real existing rights of the creators of works and the public's need to be able to use such works, where the rights situation cannot be clarified.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be found, the draft makes it possible to use the digitization of orphan works.
Projects like Europeans and other major European digitization projects, as well as our museums, archives, educational institutions, and public broadcasting will flirt.
In the future, however, it must also be about opening up the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers to the public.
In my opinion, this draft guideline and the compromise that has now been reached is indeed a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure that belongs to him holds enormous potential.
We should continue to work on this when revising the directive in two years.
Mr Vors, esteemed Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council! I would be pleased if we could also include clear language in the 2013 proposal.
We would like to see signals from the Council on how we can expand growth and competitiveness potential in Europe and, above all, how we can once again provide employment for young people.
Could you please tell us in which budget lines you intend to promote youth employment and focus on entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
Or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme or the programme for media pluralism. Here there are only cuts.
Do you really believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by guaranteeing growth and employment in those areas, by making cuts?
I heard that a growth and employment package is to be proposed by the Council.
Where can this be found in this budget, which has been submitted by the Council?
The Nordseewerk in Emmen had to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was not unexpectedly renewed.
This company, with 700 skilled jobs, is in the process of transforming from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a bulk loan and that jobs can also be saved, because the Simon colleagues at SIAC and Nordseeewen have already had to accept significant cuts in wages.

Therefore, I ask the Commission to review this procedure benevolently, but also promptly, so that these 700 jobs are not jeopardized, because these 700 jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize sustainable energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the fellow Members there suffer as a result of the state government's poor crisis management.
Goods often look harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can use them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Networks that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in suppressing the Green protest movement.
Protectors were massively abducted, arrested, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example of many.
In addition, the Commission is said to be promoting these dubious dioxins through its catalogue of measures for an innovative and competitive security industry.
The goal is to achieve, as it is called, better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk literally selling out human rights, as well as our security interests, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy.
That is why I would like to ask you to approve the amendments from us and the Social Democrats, and all of them.
I would like to ask my female colleague Regner: What do you think trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal, for example?
Demonstrations will be too few.
What active policy could the internal market implement here?
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today's debate on MiFID touches on the core area of financial market regulation.
Having made it through this legislative period, it is now about regulating the financial markets and not just looking at individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few key words.
We certainly didn't make things easy for each other last year.

We conducted a hearing in committee, carried out a survey of all stakeholders and interested groups, and based on this, developed a result through various processes, working documents, and similar materials, which we will present to the plenary for voting today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

On the one hand, we must of course acknowledge that she has done a great deal in the area of financial markets in recent years, but our interest as a parliament is that all trading of financial instruments takes place within the MiFID framework. That is why we are also introducing a new category under many conditions.

We have agreed to the so-called organized trading facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, according to the statements regarding execution and transaction and customer interaction, appropriate execution can take place at the discretion of the trading facility.
I believe that this will make an important contribution to ensuring that the entire range of OTC securities traded is traded within the MiFID world.
Another major issue that was not addressed in the last MiFID is the so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here too, our goal was to establish clear rules of the game, so that this area, which can be very dangerous and can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regulations with minimum holding periods.

Trading interruption options, with the ability to test algorithms, with the ability to view algorithms through a supervisory structure, with the introduction of a so-called TIC size regime, a minimum price size, and through corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of warning term markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here to limit the speculative component in genuine futures markets to such an extent that we do not contribute, through misguided regulations, to people in the third and fourth world being unable to buy food.
We have therefore adopted a two-pronged approach, with the aim of curbing speculation, but without harming the real economy.
With position limits, with strict upper limits for the number of contacts or positions, we want to achieve this.
However, we also want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product, using a so-called Position Che System, do not suddenly intervene in this market in a speculative manner.
Another issue that concerns us greatly is the area of investor protection.
I would just like to point out here that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The aim here is to identify the needs of specific customer groups.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex documents.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product tests, telephone recordings, relevant consultations, disclosure obligations, but also - and I would like to briefly hint at this - implementing subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member States should have the opportunity to make appropriate adjustments in accordance with their structures.
I think we're on the right track.
When my time is up, I want to thank everyone who has contributed here.
I find it a shame that it is so difficult to ensure that everyone gets four minutes of speaking time.
I would like to thank all my colleagues here at the Commission for their very constructive role in recent weeks and months.
I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council and conclude this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, first of all, thank you for the overall good cooperation on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal at key points, which has already brought about significant progress.
There will be more transparency in the area of market structures, and more comprehensive transparency, especially in the area of derivatives trading.

Under the MiFID framework, the decisions in the area of high-frequency trading in our compromise go much further than what the Commission had originally proposed and deserve the support of Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have provoked widespread public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, after major and difficult debatesâit must be saidâthis is now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now being established as binding there.
However, we still need further changes in this area to close any remaining gaps.
I also hope for further additions here through the plenary vote and eventually in the trialogue.
And it is gratifying that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament's more far-reaching proposal.
However, where the report has weaknesses is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the ability to ban products, which is progress. However, we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
As before, the distribution of financial products is not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is heavily dominated by which product offers the most commissions.
Consumers in Germany, and throughout the EU, have lost a lot of money.
Remember the open-ended real estate funds.
Unfortunately, for citizens in France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, not much will change even after our compromise.
The basic principle will continue to be commission-oriented.
To refer to subsidiarity here is a bit too simplistic.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, what will be worth it in the long run is finally good, I can only say that.
The report on type approval for category L vehicles has ultimately turned out to be a good report.
The work took longer overall than we all thought, especially than we had hoped. And there were far more pitfalls than we would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to once again express my heartfelt thanks to the rapporteur, Mr. Van der Kampf, for the truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we have still been able to achieve a lot in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur for my group, I recommend that we approve this report, even though it could have been much better.
By better, my highly esteemed colleagues, I mean of course safer.
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and thus the safety of drivers, especially that of scooter and motorcycle riders, has been a priority from the very beginning.
The number of injured motorcyclists has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is decreasing, but not in the case of motorcycle accidents in motorball.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads - that was, and that is my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This issue must be addressed in depth, especially in a regulation that is so advantageous for the internal market.
I am still convinced that this can be achieved using effective anti-lock braking system (ABS) technologies.
And I am equally convinced of its cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

Nevertheless, we have achieved that, starting in 2016, all motorcycles with 9 cubic centimeters and, starting in 2017, all existing motorcycle types with 125 cubic centimeters or more must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer.
Motor scooters can be equipped with ABS or combined braking systems, depending on the manufacturer's choice.
Unfortunately, we must admit that we have not achieved any improvement over the Commission's proposal on this point.
I would have liked to see much more here, but the Commission and the Member States have, to put it mildly, shown themselves to be very slow to act.
We did, however, succeed in getting the Commission to present a report in 2019.
The report must be based on traffic accident data from the member states and is intended to investigate the mandatory installation of ABS on motor scooters.
It shall also be forwarded to the Parliament and the Council.
On the basis of this report, the Commission will then consider making the installation of ABS in rolls mandatory.
You see, the topic remains very, very much alive.
Therefore, we will attempt to close the mandatory legislative gap starting in 2019.
I am sure that the collected data will prove me right.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheeled drivers in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future.
Mr President, Matthias Groth, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
And I believe that also applies to what we are discussing today.
I am very much in favor of us discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new development in the energy markets through unconventional resources, both in gas, predominantly in gas, but also in oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to succumb to great euphoria about the great gas future, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint dire and terrifying scenarios on the wall that have nothing to do with reality.

I think we need to bear in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to change all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and demand, and that the economic calculations of existing energy sources are now called into question.
We should face the development.

I think we should acknowledge that this can also be an opportunity for Europe, not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to positively embrace and utilize new technologies, to weigh up the opportunities and risks fairly, and to avoid falling into ideological debates. Thank you.
Commissioner, thank you for your answer. It does not entirely satisfy me.
Because I think a year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only receiving a response so late is a very, very long period.
I believe that a complainant who takes the trouble to file a complaint - and usually they have already gone through the entire legal process in their Member State - deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If you do it in this form, we should treat them accordingly.

I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates the rights. This is now a declaration about how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point: I have no objection to trying to reach a consensual clarification with the member states if it serves the cause.
But that will not always be enough.
We observe that, for example, things move relatively quickly in economic matters when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.
But when it comes to environmental issues and similar matters, where a large number of citizens demand the European Union's involvement or social rights, it becomes a bit more challenging.
I believe that these facts also need to be clearly taken into account.
For your next report, I would like us to have a clear formalization of the complainant's rights vis-Ã -vis the Commission, which are truly clear and are also well communicated.
Once again, if we really want European law to be applied, after we have gone through so much procedure here in the European Parliament, in the Council...
We have decided together. Then we must inform those who are taking care of it, those who are really committed to Europe, as well and as precisely as possible.
That is a very, very important concern for me.
I will also closely observe what has developed here next time.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, five years ago the EU's Central Asia strategy was launched.
When one asks today about the results of this strategy, the assessment is mixed.

We see how the member states individually strive to establish good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries in this region, but on the other hand, the efforts are not progressing.
Accompanying states in their transformation process towards modern democratic societies, or, as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, development is even characterized by setbacks.

Nevertheless, precisely for this reason, the European Union and its member states must express their influence in this region more strongly together, especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU countries.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only lead to the fact that competitors could assert their influence even more strongly than before in this geopolitically important country, where the emphasis on compliance with civil and human rights is not as important.
The core of the Central Asia strategy is the linking of economic interests with the commitment to safeguarding citizens' rights.
This should also form the basis for further negotiations on a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good orientation for this. Many thanks.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council! Perhaps you are following us on the Parliament's video stream, since you obviously have neither the capacity nor the desire to talk to us live.
I consider the Council's absence here and today as a gross disregard for Parliament.
Instead of evading this debate, you should rather reveal your secret for why you are opposed to any improvement of personal data protection in the fields of police and justice through a directive.

Police and justice have been plagued by data protection violations for years, not just at SWIFT, but also on a daily basis, where data of citizens who are protesting against Nazis, for example, are being unlawfully collected and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors, as well as for the police and the judiciary. This is what it's all about, in order to be able to guarantee citizens' rights.
If the Council is asked by Parliament to constructively cooperate on data protection-related regulations such as EU, PNA or Europol, then this must surely also apply to the Council in reverse.
That is why I urge you to put an end to the blockade policy in the area of data protection.
